I knew the deceased, Thomas Connor, he was also a ballast-getter—on the 5th of June he was at the Ballast-office, in Narrow-street, Ratcliff—he was very nearly drunk, and not in a fit state to go to work—I was in the street—we went down a passage leading from the street to the water-side, and when half-way down the passage he was told he was too late—we returned back—I and a per
son named Power were joking together, and in passing by, I tapped Connor at the back of his neck with a cinder—he turned round and asked what I did that for—I begged his pardon, and said I did not do it designedly—he said I ought to mind where I threw things—he stood for a minute, then turned round to the prisoner and uttered some words; I could not understand what they were, but the last word he said was "Peter"—the prisoner was standing opposite to me, with his two hands in his pockets—as soon as the words were spoken, he up with his fists and struck Connor under the left ear—he fell to the ground, with his head on the stones close to my feet—his head turned to the right side, and blood flowed from his ear—he was carried to Mr. Buchanan's, the doctor's, at the corner of Ratcliff-cross, Ratcliff-highway—I saw no more of him till I saw him at the inquest, at the London Hospital—I then saw his dead body—I do not know whether he and the prisoner were acquainted before—Connor did not attempt to strike the prisoner before he struck this blow—I could not tell whether the language Connor used to the prisoner was abusive or not, for I had ray head turned the wrong way—Connor's head came against the ground first when he fell—he fell on the back part of his head—"Peter" is a nickname of the prisoner's—he is offended at it—he has often got upbraided with that name at public-houses.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Had the prisoner been drinking? A. I do not think he had—I could not swear it—he might have had a little, but not much—this was about five o'clock in the afternoon—I had not drank any thing that day, nor for three weeks before—it was a cold cinder I hit Connor with—I had it in my hand before he came into the passage—I was skylarking with Power about a pipe of tobacco—I just pitched the cinder out of my hand—it made him angry—I was look
ing

at Power when I heard the word "Peter," and when I turned round again, I saw the prisoner strike him—Burgess and Smith, ballast-heavers, were there also—Power was not so near as me—I swear the prisoner was not the worse for liquor—he might have had two or three pints of beer, but that would not make him tipsy—Connor was not a friend of mine parti
cularly—I was a mate of his for two years, in the same craft—the prisoner had worked with us five or six months—I never had any quarrel with him.

PATRICK SMITH . I am a ballast-heaver. On the 5th of June, I was standing at Ratcliff-cross, and saw Connor going down the ballast-office passage—I saw a cinder strike him in the head as he was going down—I did not see who threw it—the prisoner was standing outside with his back to the wall—he said, "Connor, come out"—some other words passed between them which I did not hear—I saw Connor turn his head round to
wards the prisoner—the prisoner stepped out from the wall, and hit him with his right-hand on the left ear—I did not see Connor strike at the prisoner before the prisoner struck him—Connor fell down, and when he was lying down, the prisoner walked towards where he was lying, changed colour and shed tears, and said he was very sorry for it—I saw no other blow than I have mentioned—Connor appeared in liquor—I did not suppose he was angry when he went up to the prisoner—when he fell his head went on one of the paving stones of the street—he was carried to the doctor's shop.

JOHN POWER . I saw part of the transaction—I did not see the blow struck—I was standing talking to Hagerty—I saw no blow struck on either side—I saw Connor fall on his back, and saw blood coming out of his ear.

GEORGE ADAMS . I am a surgeon. I attend at the London hospital—the deceased was brought there on Saturday, the 5th of June—he was in a state of insensibility—I examined his head, and found a quantity of blood flowing from his ear—I found no mark of any blow outside—he was in the hospital till the 13th of June, and then died—he continued insensi
ble the whole time—I afterwards examined his body—his skull was frac
tured, and the brain torn considerably—there was a quantity of blood in the base of the brain—before I opened the head, I examined to see if there were any external marks—I attribute the immediate cause of his death to pressure on the brain from the blood—the appearances I saw might un
doubtedly have been occasioned by a blow or fall—it was the lower part of the skull that was fractured, behind the ear—it would very likely be occasioned by the head coming in contact with a stone—I should think it almost impossible it could have been caused by a blow from a man's fist—it was no doubt a recent injury—I do not remember seeing the wit
ness Hagerty at the hospital—I saw him before the Coroner when Con
nor's body was there—it was the same body I had examined.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 36.—Strongly recommended to mercy. —
Confined Two Years.

2211.
JOHN BROWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of Au
gust, 29 yards of woollen cloth, value 5l., the goods of
Soren Samuel Palm.

SOREN SAMUEL PALM . I live in High-street, Shadwell. On Saturday night, the 21st of August, about a quarter before ten o'clock, this cloth was at my door—I saw it move, ran immediately to the door, and saw the prisoner with it on his shoulder—I followed him across the road, laid hold of him, and brought him back into the shop with it—it is worth 5l.

Prisoner. As I was going across the road from his door, a man gave it me to carry; I went along; the prosecutor came and knocked me down and collared me; he would not go after the man. Witness. He had got across the road when I took him—I first saw him about five yards from the door—this is the cloth.
GEORGE ROBINSON (police-constable K 370.) I took the prisoner in charge—he said he was carrying it for a man behind—I saw no man behind—I came up about ten minutes after it happened.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

2212.
JOHN HOPKINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Au
gust, 1 pair of boots, value 3s. 6d., the goods of
Henry Warrener.

HENRY WARRENER . I am an apprentice to a shoemaker, and live in Strutton-ground—the prisoner lived in the same house. I left a pair of boots in the room he slept in—I missed them afterwards—these produced are them—I had placed them there on the 20th of August.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What was the prisoner in the house? A. A workman—he had been there six or seven weeks—the boots are worth 3s. 6d.—people coming into the employment have 1s. footing to pay.
JOHN JAMES LLOYD . I am a pawnbroker, and live at No. 18, Strutton-ground. I have a pair of boots, pawned by the prisoner for 1s. 6d., on the 20th of August, in the after part of the day.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you seen him before? A. Frequently.
SAMUEL BRYAN . I am a policeman. I took him in charge—he said he knew nothing of it—I found the duplicate in the cell he was locked up in.

JOHN JAMES LLOYD
re-examined. This is the duplicate of them.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Three Months.

2213.
ALEXANDER WETHERLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 13th of August, 1 plane, value 4s.; 1 square, value 2s.; and 1 auger, value 1s.; the goods of
George Cock; and that he had been before con
victed of felony.

GEORGE COCK . I am a carpenter, and live at Putney. On Friday, the 13th of August, I was at work on the top of a building at Putney—I went to dinner at twelve o'clock, leaving some tools on the building—I missed them about a quarter after one, when I came back—they were worth 7s.—these are them—(produced.)

WILLIAM PARKER (police-constable T 47.) I was on duty at Chiswick on the 13th of August. I stopped the prisoner in Devonshire-row, with one plane, one square, and an auger—I asked where he got them—he said they were his own property, he had brought them from his own home; that he took them to Hammersmith to pawn, but they refused to take them—I stopped him five miles from Cock's premises, at a quarter to seven o'clock, the same night as the robbery
ing

JOHN JONES (police-constable T 31.) I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's former conviction, which I got from the Clerk of the Peace of Clerkenwell Sessions—(read)—he is the person—I have known him ele
ven years.

GUILTY .* Aged 53.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2214.
WILLIAM HALL was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of Ja
nuary, 1 sovereign, 1 half-crown, and 4 shillings; the monies of
James Beamont, his master.

JOHN BEAMONT . I am a baker, and live in Sophia-street, Poplar. On the 2nd of January the prisoner was in my service—I gave him a sove
reign, a half-crown, and four shillings, to go to Ratcliff Mill for half a sack of flour—I usually have my flour from there—I had sent him there once before—he did not return, but was taken into custody six months after
wards.

GEORGE SWEET . I know the prisoner—I have seen him several times at Ratcliff Mill—at this distance of time I cannot charge my memory whe
ther he came on the 2nd of January or not—I believe he did not—I have no entry of his coming, and I enter all the goods I deliver—I delivered several parcels of flour that day on account of Mr. Beamont, but I have no recollection of seeing the prisoner.

WILLIAM SLADDEN . I am a policeman. I apprehended the prisoner on the 17th of August—I said, "Do you know what I want you for?"—he said, "Oh yes, I have been very uneasy in my mind for the last week; I have been expecting it"—as I brought him to the office, he said he had been sliding, and lost the money, and was afraid to go back to his master, and that he left the barrow at the mill.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not like to go back, because I had lost the money.

MR. BEAMONT re-examined. I had no character with him—he was with me about twelve months—he once stopped away with a little money I gave him to go to town with, but I forgave him that, and he worked it out—the barrow was found at the mill.
NOT GUILTY .

2215.
ELIZABETH M'GUMRY was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of August, 90 1/4 yards of printed cotton, value 4s. 9d. the goods of
William James Stevenson.

JOHN GIBSON BROWN . I am apprentice to William James Stevenson, a linen-draper, in Ratcliff-highway. On Saturday, the 21st of August, I was serving a customer, and saw the prisoner come into the shop, go to the counter, and look at a shawl which laid on it—she took it up—I saw her pull up her dress, and put the shawl so as to screen herself—I called Mr. Brown forwards, he came forward—she asked the price of a shawl, which was 2s.—she bid 1s. 6d., and he went to the other end of the shop, and she went out—I saw she walked with difficulty, and called Brown again—she was fetched back, and as she came into the shop she made a shuffle with her legs—Brown said, "Now I will search you, and see what you have got"—he moved her away, and there was the dress underneath—she had left the shawl on the counter before she went out—I am certain the dress was not on the floor till she came back.
Prisoner. I never laid my hand on any thing on the counter except the shawl—I offered 1s. 6d.—he refused, and I went out—when I came

back, I shuffled my clothes, because my petticoat was coming off, but I never had it—he said, "You must have had it about you;" but I had never seen it. Witness. It was on the counter about an hour, or an hour and a half before she came into the shop—I noticed the floor particularly before she came in—there was nothing on the floor at all before she came back—here is a mark on the dress.
JURY. Q. Were you behind the counter? A. Yes, I was behind the opposite counter—the gown-piece laid a yard and a half from where she was—it was found about a yard and a half from the counter.

THOMAS WILLIAM BROWN . I am shopman to Mr. Stevenson. The witness spoke to me—I went to the counter where the prisoner was—she offered 1s. 6d. for the shawl—I then moved to the other end of the shop—I showed her another shawl, and said it was much better than the one she was looking at—I observed something rather bulky at the lower part of her person, but I did not like to examine her—I walked further down the shop—the witness called to me to observe her difficulty in walking—she could hardly walk, as she had the dress between her legs—observing her difficulty in walking, I fetched her back—she slipped from my hold—I followed her into the shop, and said, "Now I will see what you have"—she shifted her legs—I said, "Let me see what you have dropped"—I moved her on one side, and there was the dress—she imme
diately said, "You did not see me take it, though," and said I did it through spite, because she would not buy the shawl—I bad seen the dress on the counter not ten minutes or a quarter of an hour before—the bulky appearance of the lower part of her stomach was gone when the dress was found.
Prisoner. You did not follow me. Witness. Yes, I did, and took hold of you.

JAMES GIFFORD . I am a policeman. The prisoner was given into my custody—at the station the inspector asked where she slept last night—she said she did not know, nor where she slept the night before—she said she did not take the dress.
Prisoner's Defence. I never had the dress in my possession—my own clothes were falling off, and I put my hand down to hold them on.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Two Months.

2216.
WILLIAM SEAL was indicted
for feloniously and knowingly uttering, on the 9th of August, a forged request for the delivery of goods, with intent to defraud
Lowther Jackson.

LOWTHRR JACKSON . I am a tailor and outfitter, and live in Three Colt-street, Limehouse. On Tuesday, the 9th of August, the prisoner, who is a stranger, came into my shop, looked round, and said, "I think I have got in to the wrong shop"—I asked what he wanted—he said, "A suit of clothes"—I said I could make them as cheap as any other person, and they would be 2l. 10s.,—he looked at some things at the door, and said he wanted a pilot-coat, which came to 1l. 15s.—my foreman mea
sured him for the cloth—he turned round and asked me to lend him some money, as he had just come home—I lent him 2s. 6d.—he said he had come home in the Calcutta ship, and had been a long trading voyage—he came again between eight and nine o'clock at night, and wanted more money—I said I could not give him any till I made inquiry—he pulled a paper out of his pocket, and said, "I have given my captain your card,

and he is going to send four or five more men to supply with clothes—he asked for a black silk handkerchief, which I gave him, and then a cotton one—I said I should send down to his captain next morning, in the West India Dock, to make inquiry; and my young man did go—this is the paper which the prisoner produced to me—I furnished him with two handker
chiefs, a silk and a cotton one, on the credit of that paper, believing it at the time to be true—I said, "Why, you told me you belonged to the Calcutta, and this says the Mary Jane"—he said, "Oh, no, I am bound to Calcutta on a trading voyage"—(paper read)—"Ship Mary Jane. Mr. Jackson,—Please let the bearer have clothes what he wants—for Cook, William Johnson—William Nargot, Captain; owner, Mr. Red
man."—he was dressed as if he had just come off a voyage.

Prisoner. I left the West India Dock; I had no money, I had spent it all; I met a man, who said, "My father can let you have goods till you get your pay;" we went to Jackson's; he gave me his card; the man measured me for the coat; I went at night and said, "Lend me a shilling to get a drop of beer?" he said he would give me half-a-crown, which he did; he gave me a card; he said, "If you want money come to me, I will let you have money and clothes;" I had a neck handkerchief and a pocket handker
chief. Witness. I did not supply him with any goods subsequent to the order being presented—before he brought the order I lent him half-a-crown.
Prisoner. I did not give him that paper. Witness. I swear he did—he came in by himself.

HENRY GRIFFITHS . I am traveller to Mr. Jackson. I went to the West India Docks to inquire for the Mary Jane—I saw the prisoner—he said the vessel laid in the dry docks—I said, "Is the captain on board?"—he said "Yes"—I said, "You had better come on board with me"—he said, "No, I have to go on a message, I will come by and by"—I found a vessel of that name at last—I found an old man on board—there was a broom at the mast, which intimated that the vessel was for sale—she had no appearance of having gone a voyage—he said the vessel was lying in the dry docks, but I could not find her there at all.

Prisoner. Q. Who gave you soup at the galley? A. I never had any—he invited me to breakfast in the morning when he gave Mr. Jack
son the note;

GEORGE ROBINSON (police-sergeant I 36.) The prisoner was given into my custody in High-street, Shadwell—I took him to Mr. Jackson's shop—the prisoner asked to look at the paper—Mr. Jackson had not got it with him then.

MARY POWELL . I am the wife of William Powell, and live in Narrow-street, Limehouse. The prisoner came to me, and said he had come from the captain who had just come home in the Mary Jane, and the captain had sent him to lodge at my house—I asked his name—he said, William Seal, and that I was to go with him in the morning to the captain to know what he was to pay, but he was to go and tell the captain what was the charge for his week's board and lodging—I said 14s. a week—he went away, and came back again—I gave him tea—he went out after tea, and said he was going to buy a few things—he said his ship came from Africa—he came back again with a few things, and said he had paid 6s. for the black silk handkerchief, and 1s. 6d. for the pocket handkerchief, and asked if I thought them dear—I said, "I do not know"—he had supper, and break
fast in the morning, and never paid for it.
Prisoner. The woman is right enough; I do not know any thing about the paper nor about Mr. Jackson; the other man tells the truth.

LOWTHER JACKSON
re-examined. He is the man, and he brought that paper—I have listened to all that has been said against me and have nothing to say.
Prisoner. That young man brought the order into the shop.

GUILTY .* Aged 23.—
Confined Two Years.

2217.
THOMAS SULLIVAN was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of July, 1 saucepan, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Richard Powell: 1 plane, value 1s. 6d.; and 1 kettle, value 6d. the goods of
John Cayzer: and
CATHERINE SULLIVAN
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

JOHN CAYZER . I am a carpenter, and live in China-place, St. George's. My house stands in a yard by itself—I have a bench and other things in that yard—I came home on Monday night, the 5th of July, a little after twelve o'clock—I found my yard gate open, and the house door also—I sent for my son to fetch a light, and found the prisoner, Thomas Sullivan, under the bench—I pulled him out, and asked what brought him there—he said his father had been beating him, and he came to sleep there—I was going to give him a shaking, but in coming through the passage I stum
bled over a stove and a blue dish, and I gave him in charge of a policeman—he at first denied having touched the things in the passage—he afterwards said he had moved them out of the yard to take over to his mother—I missed a saucepan that night—I asked him about it, and a kettle—he said he did not know any thing about it—I missed the plane in the morning—I had used it the evening before at dusk.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Do you leave your gate loose? A. In the day-time, not in the night, it is left so that we know how to undo it, but it is shut so that strangers cannot open it—I have not found the kettle—I cannot prove the prisoner took it, but it was missing at the time.
NOT GUILTY .

p.hi: Fifth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
2218.
RICHARD TOWNSHEND was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of August, 2 breast-pins, value 10s.; and 1 sovereign; the property of
Henry Burfield; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Confined Three Months.

2219.
RICHARD SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of August, 4 spoons, value 14s., the goods of
Henry Heathorn; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .**—
Confined Six Months.

2220.
MARY ANN DIXON was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of August, 3 spoons, value 10s.; 1 shawl, value 4s.; and 1 handkerchief, value 3s.; the goods of
James Davy, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

2221.
WILLIAM STRONG was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of July, 1 coat, value 2l. 10s., the goods of
Joseph Russell; and that he had been before convicted of felony; to which he pleaded

GUILTY .—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

2222.
GEORGE TATHAM was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of August, 1 necklace, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Joseph Barnett, from the person of
Samuel Barnett.

ANN BARNETT . I live with my father, a labourer, in Fleur-de-lis-court, Spitalfields. About five o'clock in the evening of Tuesday, the 17th of August, I was crossing Stewart-street with my brother Samuel in my arms—he is six months old—I felt a snatch, and missed a necklace from his neck—I turned round and saw Mr. Cheesman, and saw the prisoner running—I did not see who did it—Mr. Cheesman ran after him and over
took him—the necklace was produced by Mr. Phillips.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you known the prisoner before? A. No.

ROBERT CHEESMAN . I saw the prisoner go behind the witness, snatch the beads off the child's neck, and run away—I followed him—he ran off and threw them down—I took them up and pursued him till the policeman took him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you want to get any money of any body? A. No—when I left the Magistrate on the 18th, I went to a public-house and had a pint of half-and-half—a man followed me who represented him-self to be related to the prisoner—his father and mother said, "You have no occasion, as your deposition is not taken, to appear again"—I said I must, and a man said, "I will pay your expenses if you will go out of the way"—I inquired of my solicitor, and he said if I took any thing I should be liable to be indicted—I had appointed to meet the prisoner's father (seeing them in such distress) on the Friday evening, at six o'clock, at the sign of the Raven, in Mile-end-road, but when I found that I should be wrong to do it, I sent a person to the father on Friday morning to say I would not meet him—I did net ask 3s. a day for three weeks from the father—it was mentioned by the father and others of the party—I did not get a farthing.
COURT. Q. Did you know the prisoner before? A. No, I never saw him—on my solemn oath I saw him take the necklace from the child's neck.

MICHAEL CONWAY (police-constable H 138.) I saw the prisoner run
ning, and took him—Cheesman came to the station-house and said he saw him take the beads from the child's neck—the prisoner did not say any thing.

Cross-examined. Q. Did he say nothing? A. I asked him if he had seen any necklace—he said no—when the depositions were taken he said he was very sorry—I do not recollect him saying any thing about the beads in my presence.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined One Month.—The last Week Solitary.

2223.
BENJAMIN EVERETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of August, 28lbs. weight of coffee, value 2l. 5s. and 1 bag, value 6d.; the goods of
John Chatfield.

THOMAS ISRAEL BUNDY . I am servant to Mr. John Chatfield, who lives in Aldgate. On the 12th of August I put this bag of coffee at his door, inside—I saw it safe at ten o'clock, and soon after the street-keeper spoke to me, I then missed it.

GEORGE TEAKLE (police-sergeant H 8.) I stopped the prisoner with this bag of coffee, in Essex-street, Whitechapel, about eleven o'clock in the morning—there was another roan with him, whom we took, but he made his escape—the prisoner said he received it of that man.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How far is it from the prose
cutor's shop to where you took the prisoner? A. About five minutes, walk—the prosecutor's shop could not be seen from there.
NOT GUILTY .

2224.
ELIZABETH JONES was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of August, 1 shawl, value 10s., the goods of
George Liddimore.

MARY LIDDIMORE . I am the wife of George Liddimore; we live in Old Gravel-lane. The prisoner lodged with me—I went out and came home on the 14th of August—the prisoner left my house that evening—I missed my shawl—I spoke to her about it—she told me where she had pawned it, and I found it there.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. I believe her husband is your own brother? A. Yes—I gave her in charge through my husband—I be
lieve she would have redeemed it—she was in distress.
NOT GUILTY .

2225.
GEORGE HOLLAND was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of August, 2 gowns, value 7s.; 1 shirt, value 1s.; 1 pair of stockings, value 3d.; and 1 handkerchief, value 3d.; the goods of
Ann Woodman; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ANN WOODMAN. I lodge at Mrs. Hurst's. I found the prisoner in my room about four o'clock in the day, on the 19th of August—he was partly undressed—he had a pair of my stockings on his legs, and my handker
chief in his pocket—Mrs. Hurst had found these gowns and shirt before she called me—they are my property—the prisoner had no business in my room.

MARIA HURST . I live in Went worth-street The prisoner came to lodge in my house on the night of the 18th of August—I called him at nine o'clock the next morning—he got up, came down, and appeared very, ill and very sick—I said, "You don't seem well, would a bason of tea be of any use to you?"—he said, "Yes, and thank you too"—I said, "You had better go and lie down again"—he went up, and laid till four—I then went to him to know if he would get up—he said, "Yes"—I went up again in about ten minutes, and could not see him in his room—I looked in another room, he was not there—I then looked in the further room, and he was standing by Mrs. Woodman's bed-side—I said, "What are you doing?"—he said, "I don't know"—I found this gown in his hat—I said, "You are robbing the woman"—I locked the door, ran down, and called Mrs. Woodman up—when I went up again he was half undressed—he was dressed when I first saw him, and I suppose he had these things on him, as there was nothing on the bed when I went down, and when I came up again some of these things were on the bed, and the rest on him.
PIERCE DRISCOLL (police-constable H 24.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2226.
THOMAS M'DONNELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of July, 1 coat, value 18s., the goods of
Isaac Joscelyne.

ISAAC JOSCELYNE . I am a tailor, and live in Shoreditch. On the morn
ing of the 10th of July I put a summer coat at my door—I missed it in about an hour—it was brought back by my shopman, and this now produced is it.

ROBERT SCALES . I am a letter-sorter in the Post-office. I was near the prosecutor's door that morning—I saw the prisoner and another lad together—they went to Mr. Joscelyne's shop, and sat down a little while—the prisoner then changed his apron with the other—the other then took the coat off the horse, and the prisoner ran away with it.
Prisoner I was at work at Woolwich that day, seven miles from here.

GUILTY .** Aged 18.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2227.
MARTHA CORBETT was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of September, 1840, 10 printed books, value 2l.; 9 blankets, value 2l. 5s.; 2 pairs of pillow-cases, value 6s.; 1 table-cloth, value 5s.; 5 sheets, value 2l. 10s.; 1 carpet, value 3s.; 2 handkerchiefs, value 4s.; 1 sheet, value 12s.; 2 towels, value 1s. 6d.; 2 pillows, value 10s.; 2 quilts, value 10s.; 1 pair of boots, value 9s.; 1 carpet-cover, value 10s.; and 4 dishes, value 18s.; the goods of
William Thurnell, her master.

MARY THURNELL . I am the wife of William Thurnell, of Regent-place, City-road. The prisoner was my servant—I searched her boxes, and found nothing—I then searched her person, and found four duplicates of a blanket, a bolster, a pillow, pawned at Mr. Somers's—they are mine—my husband afterwards found about thirty-eight more duplicates in the kitchen.
WILLIAM HUMPHREYS . I live at Mr. Somers's, a pawnbroker. I have a bolster, pillow, and two blankets, pawned by the prisoner.

Prisoner. Mary Ann, their niece, asked me to pawn these things—I did not refuse it, but I gave all the money I received for them to Mary Ann, and she gave it to her sister, who was discharged. On Satur
day night, the 14th, my mistress accused me of taking these things, and turned me out of doors at twelve o'clock at night—I told her her niece gave me them, but she would not hear what I had to say, because they were in my name. She owes me a quarter's wages, which is 2l. 1s.

MRS. THURNELL re-examined. I have a niece, named Mary Ann Smith—she positively denies every thing of the kind—she was before the Magistrate, but her evidence was not wanted—she is nineteen years old, and has a good character—she has a sister, who is married.

GUILTY . Aged 49.—
Confined One Year.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2228.
JOHN SHANLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of August, 1 half-crown, 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Benjamin Bullock.

WILLIAM HENRY PERKS . I am in the service of Mr. Benjamin Bullock, who keeps a ham and beef shop, in St. John-street. On the 27th of August, between eleven and twelve o'clock, I was in the back room, and heard a noise, I went into the shop, and saw the prisoner leaning over the counter, and the till was out to its full extent—I asked what he had got in his hand—I found in his right hand three pence, and in his left hand, which he put behind him, a half-crown, a shilling, and a sixpence—I looked into the till, and missed a half-crown from it.
Prisoner. The half-crown was my own; my mother sent me with it to buy some ham and beef.

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

2229.
GEORGE PEARSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 25th of August, 1 coat, value 10s., the goods of
John Barker.

JOHN BARKER . I live in Old-street, and am a cab driver. On the 25th of August I drove my cab to the Old-street rank—I went into a public-house, and was there about a quarter of an hour—I came out, and missed this coat, which I had left on my cab.

WILLIAM BROWN CROSS (police-constable G 217.) At half-past eight o'clock that evening I was in Cowper-street, and stopped the prisoner with this coat—he said it was his own, and he had brought it from home—that was about a quarter of an hour after the prosecutor left it on the cab.

GUILTY .** Aged 20.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2230.
DENNIS O'CONNELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 28th of July, 2 hearth-rugs, value 1l. 5s. 4d., the goods of
James Henry Osland.

JAMES HENRY OSLAND . I am a hearth-rug manufacturer, and live in John-street, Spitalfields. The prisoner was in my service as rug-weaver—he came on the 28th of July, and asked me to let him have two rugs, as he had a customer for them—I was unwilling to let him have them at first. but as he was to bring back the money or the rugs at six o'clock the same night, I let him have two—he did not return—it was three weeks before I could find him.
HENRY HALL . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Baldwin's-gardens. I produce one of these rugs, which I took in of Mrs. O'Niel.

ANNA O'NIEL . I pawned this rug—the prisoner was in a court, with three or four women—one of them sent her little girl, and asked me to take this to pawn, and I took it in my own name—I gave the money and the ticket to the prisoner.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

2231.
ELIZABETH ALGAR was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of August, 1 pewter-pot, value 1s. the goods of
Stephen Brown.

RICHARD BROWN . I live with my uncle, Stephen Brown, who keeps the King's Arms public-house, in Dock-street, Ratcliff. On the 21st of August the prisoner came into the place—when she went out I missed the pot—I followed her, and took this pint-pot out of her apron—it was my master's—she said she was going to bring it back again directly.

Prisoner's Defence. I had some gin and beer; I was very much over
come; I said I was going to bring it back again.

GUILTY . Aged 43.—
Confined Three Months.

2232.
WILLIAM WELLHAM was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of August, 1 pair of boots, value 9d., the goods of
George Ruby; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ELIZABETH RUBY . I am the wife of George Ruby—we live in Arthur-street, Chelsea. On the 20th of August the prisoner came and begged at our house—I told him we had nothing for him—he came again in the afternoon to buy a file—when he left, I missed a pair of boots from the shop—I called him back, and said, "My boy, you have got a pair of boots"—he put down his basket, and I saw these boots in it, which are ours—he ran away.
TIMOTHY WELLS (police-constable V 83.) I took the prisoner—I asked him if be had stolen the boots—he denied it—in going to the station, he said he had stolen them.
Prisoner. The woman called me back to buy a halfpenny-worth of pears; another boy told me to go and steal an old pair of boots, and put them into the basket.
HENRY KIMBER (police-sergeant V 20.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person who was tried.

GUILTY .—
Transported for Seven Years.—Convict Ship.

2233.
THOMAS WALKER was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of August, 1 cloak, value 10s., the goods of
Joseph Barnett; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

MARY BARNETT . I am the wife of Joseph Barnett, a cooper, and live in Thomas-street, Whitechapel. On the evening of the 7th of August I hung my cloak up behind my parlour door, and on the 11th I missed it.

ELIZABETH LEACH . I am servant to Mr. Cowderoy, a starch-manu
facturer, in Thomas-street. On Friday, the 11th of August, I was at the nursery window, which is opposite Mr. Barnett's—I saw the prisoner go in, and take the cloak, and come out with it—I am sure he is the man.
Prisoner. I am not the person. Witness. Yes, he is the person—he had a red neck handkerchief on—there was another with him.
JURY. Q. Had you ever seen him before? A. Yes, I had seen him, and I watched him.
GEORGE SMITH (City police-constable, No. 337.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2234.
THOMAS FINNIGAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of August, 14lbs. weight of nails, value 3s., the goods of
John Jay, his master.

ROWLAND MORGAN . I live in Hampton-street, Gray's-inn-road, and am a carpenter. The prisoner was employed as a plasterer's labourer for my master, Mr. John Jay—he had no right to have any nails in his business—I cannot swear to these nails, but I had just such—I could not miss any, I had such a number in my care—he had no right to take any away.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were these nails lying about? A. I cannot say that none of them were lying about—I remember the pri
soner being employed there about three months.

GEORGE HANBURY (police-constable D 102.) I stopped the prisoner in the Uxbridge-road, on the 26th of August, with a basket on his shoulder—I asked what he had got—he said, "Chips, and a bottle"—I searched, and found these nails—I asked how he came by them—he said he brought them from where he had been at work, at Mr. Jay's, the builder, and was going to nail a box up—I searched him at the station, and found on him as many more nails as I could hold in my hands—I said next morning that he was very foolish in taking them—he said he picked them up in one room and another.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 32.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Two Months.

2235.
WILLIAM COLLINS was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of June, 1 saw, value 2s., the goods of
Joseph Fletcher.

JOSEPH JEX . I am apprentice to Mr. Joseph Fletcher, a ship-builder, it Limehouse—his yard is at Poplar—the prisoner is one of my fellow-ap
prentices. I lost a saw of my master's about three months ago—I inquired, but could not hear of it—Mr. Dicker showed it me again—this is it— (looking at it)—I know it by two marks on the handle of it, and a mark on the back.

JAMES RICHARD WATTS . I am servant to Mr. Dicker, the pawnbroker, in Commercial-road. I know the prisoner—I had seen him before—on the 8th of June I took in this saw of him—I am sure he is the person.

Prisoner. I am innocent; I have pledged tools frequently for one Clark; he told me had a chest of tools, and seeing the distress he and his mother were in, I pawned them, not knowing I was doing wrong.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 17—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Eight Days.

2236.
WILLIAM COLLINS was again indicted with
JOHN CLARK
for a misdemeanor.

STEPHEN DANIEL SKELLY . I live in Ebenezer-place, Commercial-road—I am an ironmonger—my father is foreman to Mr. Fletcher—I am in the habit, on my father's messages, of supplying tools to Mr. Fletcher's apprentices. On the 17th of August Clark came to me, and said he had, come for a plane by my father's order—I let him have a plane, fully be
lieving he was authorised to come by my father.

DANIEL SKELLY . I am foreman in Mr. Fletcher's yard. When tools are wanted I am in the habit of sending the apprentices to my son for them—I did not give Clark any order on the 17th to get any plane from my son.

THOMAS DICKER . I am a pawnbroker. On the 18th of August Collins came in with this new jack plane to pawn—I asked if it was his own—he said no, it belonged to an apprentice of Mr. Curling's, who was outside—I told him to bring him in—he went out—Clark came in with him, and said it was his.

STEPHEN DANIEL SKELLY
re-examined. This is exactly the sort of plane we sold to Clark.

CLARK—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Three Months.

COLLINS—
NOT GUILTY .

2237.
WILLIAM BURNHAM was indicted
for embezzlement.

HENRY JOHN KINGHAM . I keep the King's Arms public-house, in Claremont-row, Islington. The prisoner was my pot-boy—it was his duty to take out beer, and to receive money—if he received the monies stated in this indictment he has not paid it to me.
ELIZABETH VILLETT . I took beer of the prisoner—I paid him 6d. a day for his master up to the 18th of August.
BENJAMIN GOODWIN (police-constable G 114.) The prisoner came to me voluntarily, and said he had been robbing his master, and wished to give himself up.
Prisoner. I have a wife and three children to support; my wages were but 4s. a week; I thought of making it up, and offered to pay my master.

GUILTY. Aged 23.—Recommended to mercy by the Jury. —
Confined Three Months.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2238.
PURSGLOVE LESLEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of August, 1 pair of boots, value 5s., the goods of
William Henry Cox.

CATHERINE COX . I am the wife of William Henry Cox, a shoemaker, and live in the City-road. The prisoner occupied a furnished room in our house. On Saturday, the 21st of August, he did not come home at night, and on Sunday morning I missed three pairs of boots, which had been safe in the shop as late as half-past twelve on Saturday night—about three the next afternoon I went up to the prisoner's bed-room, and to my great sur
prise I found him there—I asked him how he came there—he told me not to be alarmed, that he had got over the Lying-in-Hospital wall, and in at the back parlour window—he went out—I went up to his room, and saw the string of these boots part of the way out of his portmanteau, which stood under the window—I told my husband—he got a policeman—in the even
ing the prisoner came home, and was accused of it—he said he was guilty, and he meant to return them.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Are these the boots? A. Yes— they are torn by the lace-holes—they have been tried on some one—we rather think the prisoner had a female into the house—he could get one in by opening the door when he was in the house—I think some female must have had these on—no man could have got them on—the prisoner said he was drunk—I said, "I have a charge to make about a pair of drab boots I have missed"—he said, "I know I have taken them, they are in my port
manteau"—he gave the policeman the key, and the boots were there—he had been at home nine or ten weeks—he gets drunk most abominably, and then he is the most troublesome fellow that ever came into a house.
NOT GUILTY .

2239.
BARTHOLOMEW HARRINGTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of August, 2lbs. 14oz. weight of bacon, value 2s., the goods of
James Osborn.

ANN OSBORN . I am the wife of James Osborn—we keep a shop at Walham-green, Fulham. On the 17th of August the prisoner came in, took up this bacon, and looked at it—I kept my eye on him—he turned round, put the bacon under his jacket, and walked out—I followed him, and never lost sight of him till I gave him in charge, with the bacon on him.
Prisoner. Q. Where was I? A. I followed you into Mr. Giles's shop—I had not time to say any thing to you when you took it—you ran out of the shop.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Confined Three Months.

2240.
DANIEL RICKETTS,
THOMAS SKIGGS , and
WILLIAM BENNETT were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of July, 3 trusses of hay, value 10s., the goods of
Michael Woodhouse.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
James Gingell.

MICHAEL WOODHOUSE . I gave directions to send two loads of hay to Whitechapel-market—Gingell was my salesman—I have a little boy named Ebenezer Woodhouse—Ricketts was my carter—it was his duty to carry the hay to Whitechapel.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. You are a farmer, and grow hay and clover? A. Yes—my hay-binder is not here—I know nothing about two loads being bound up—Gingell's business is to sell the hay—he pays me the money when I like to go after it—sometimes a month or two passes—he always passes me the bills of parcels back from the man that has it—I do not recollect the price at all—I expect the salesman to do the best he can for me—Ricketts has been in my service sixteen years—he was always honest for any thing I know—he lives in my house as in-door servant.
MR. DOANE. Q. Have you been paid for this hay? A. Yes, by Gingell.

WILLIAM BYERS . I am in the service of Mr. Gingell, a salesman in the hay market, Whitechapel. On the 10th of July, Mr. Banks, the ma
naging-man for Mr. Rhodes, came to purchase two loads of hay—there was a wagon of Mr. Woodhouse's, which had two loads on it—I sold it for two loads, seventy-two trusses—Ricketts and a little boy came with it—I promised to send this hay to Banks's, for Mr. Rhodes—I did not expect to be paid till he received it—Ricketts and the boy went with it—they were to go direct to Mr. Rhodes at Stoke Newington—they had no right to go any where else.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. You know the mode of this business? A. Yes—the hay-carts are driven into High-street, White
chapel, when a purchaser comes, and we make the bargain—I agreed to sell this for six guineas a load—I told Mr. Banks I could not take less—Rhodes had dealt with me before—they used to pay once in six weeks, or when we liked to take a bill—I cannot tell when they paid for it—it was a goodish bit after it was sold—perhaps a month.

WILLIAM BANKS .—I am foreman to Messrs. Rhodes. I purchased two loads of hay—they were to be delivered before I paid for them—they were to be sent to Stoke Newington. On Saturday morning, the 10th of July, I went and saw some clover—I asked Byers the price, he said, "Six gui
neas"—I desired him to send two loads to Stoke Newington—there were seventy-two trusses in two loads—I presumed he sent it home—I got home twenty minutes before twelve o'clock—when I got home, I found the wagon and hay had arrived—I saw Searing and Carswell, and in conse
quence of what Carswell said to me, I went to the station—I got Mr. Pritchard and an officer, and took Ricketts into custody for stealing three trusses of clover—I went with Pritchard to the Elephant public-house, and

saw Pritchard speak to Bennett, the ostler—after going into one place and another, I saw three trusses of clover—I said, "These are three I pur
chased this morning"—there was other hay of different descriptions— Pritchard asked how it came there—Bennett hemmed and hawed, and then said he purchased it last Thursday—these three trusses were worth 10s. 6d.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Was not what you said that they were three you thought were yours? A. Yes, they looked like mine—it has turned out since that only two were of the same kind as mine—they are all three of the same quality—I speak from merely seeing it in the cart, and then looking at it in the stable.

Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. I suppose at Whitechapel, there are public-houses? A. I seldom go into one, except to have a bit of bread and cheese—I cannot tell whether I did that morning—I cannot recollect Byers and I going to a public-house—it is not customary to bind the bargain—I agreed to give six guineas a load.

JOSEPH SEARING . I live at Cheshunt, in Herts. On this Saturday, I was driving a horse and cart—I saw Woodhouse's wagon with two loads of hay—I saw Ricketts and the boy on the top, and Skiggs was driving the wagon—they stopped at the Elephant—Rickett's got off, and went with Skiggs into the house, and had some beer, Skiggs then came and took the fore horse, and Ricketts drove the hind horse, and turned down the street by the stable-door—I saw Bennett by the stable—I saw Skiggs undo the ropes—Ricketts got on the top, and took three trusses down, the first Bennett took in his arms, the next truss Ricketts set down on the ground—then he took the other down, and Ricketts spread the cloth over the remainder of the clover—then Bennett, Ricketts, and the boy came to the door, and Bennett gave Ricketts some money—I do not know how much.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How many times have you been charged with felony? A. Never.

EBENEZER WOODHOUSE . I am nephew of Mr. Woodhouse. I am twelve years old—I came up with two loads of my uncle's hay on this occasion—Ricketts was the carman—after that I went with Ricketts to Mr. Rhodes's—before we got out of Whitechapel, Skiggs came to us—after he came up, Ricketts got on the top of the wagon, and Skiggs drove—they stopped at the Elephant, in the Kingsland-road—we stopped there, and Skiggs took the fore horse, and Ricketts drove the hind horse, and took the wagon down by the side of the public-house stable—I saw Ben
nett by the side of the stable—Skiggs undid the ropes, and Ricketts put the head of the tilt up, and then put three trusses of hay down—Bennett got them, and put them into the stable—Bennett and Ricketts had some drink, and Skiggs went on with the wagon—Bennett gave Ricketts some money, and then I went on after the wagon.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where were you all the time? A. On the wagon—Skiggs drove it round into the high road again—I saw Mr. Searing behind with his cart—I did not tell any body about it.

ALLAN CARSWELL . I am in the service of Messrs. Rhodes—when the wagon arrived there were sixty-nine trusses—there ought to have been seventy-two—I remember Mr. Banks returning from the market before the prisoners left the yard—Skiggs was in the yard at the time.
Cross-examined by MR. CHAMBERS. Q. What are you? A. Assistant in
the yard—I count all the trusses, unless Mr. Bennett is there—the men were given in charge—Mr. Woodhouse saw the hay found at Bennett's.
JAMES DANIELS . I accompanied the inspector to Messrs. Rhodes, and there took Ricketts into custody.

BENJAMIN PRITCHARD . I am an inspector of police—I went with Banks to the Elephant—I saw Bennett, who is ostler there—I asked him to allow me to go into his stable—he made no difficulty—I said I suspected there was hay that had been stolen—he opened the lock, and we found nothing there—he opened another stable—there were three trusses of hay, which Mr. Banks pointed out—there were other trusses of very different sort all together—Mr. Banks said, "How came they here; how long have you had them"—he hesitated, and said, "Oh, on Thursday."
THOMAS RICHARDS (police-constable N 208.) I took Skiggs—he asked what for, I told him—he said he would make them pay well for his time.
(Bennett received a good character.)

RICKETTS—
GUILTY . Aged 42.—
Confined Three Months.

SKIGGS—
GUILTY . Aged 29.

BENNETT—
GUILTY . Aged 32.
Confined Nine Months.
(There was another indictment against Ricketts and Skiggs.)

2241.
CHARLES HUGHES and
JAMES BROWN were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of August, 2 breast-pins and 1 chain, value 5s., the goods of a man unknown, from his person.

CHARLES JACKSON (police-constable A 146.) On Saturday afternoon, the 7th of August, I saw the two prisoners, in company with two others, near Westminster-Bridge—there was a rowing-match—I saw them walk
ing at the back of different people, up and down the bridge—after watch
ing them some minutes, I saw one, not in custody, put his hand over, and take something from a gentleman's breast, which was immediately handed to Hughes, who was standing on the other side of the way—Brown was covering the man who took the pin—Hughes put something into his pocket—I immediately went over to him, took hold of his arm, and took this pin from his trowsers' pocket—the same pocket he had put the pin into—he had not got his hand out—at the same time another officer came up—I gave Hughes to him, and took Brown—I am sure he was covering the other man—my brother constable and I went to the spot where the pin was stolen from—I held it up, and asked what gentleman in the crowd had lost a pin—one gentleman turned round, and said, "This is my pro
perty, drawn from my breast"—there were the marks of the pin in his stock—we asked him to accompany us to the station, but in going we missed him, or he missed us—we have heard nothing of him since.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was there a good crowd of people? A. Yes—Brown stood Behind the other—when we took Hughes, Brown had got eight or nine yards—he was within our sight, and could see us.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Where were you standing when you saw them first? A. On the other side of the way—but when the boats were starting off, I saw them closing on a gentleman—I was half-way across when the pin was handed to Hughes.
JOHN PASMORE MUMFORD (police-constable A 35.) I saw the prisoners

and two others walking behind the persons who were looking through the balustrades—I saw Jackson cross and take Hughes, and take the pin from the lining of his pocket—I took him, and heard the gentleman say it was his pin—I had seen the prisoners in company before this.

WILLIAM MORRIS (police-sergeant A 20.) I know the prisoners—they are acquainted—I saw them together on the 26th and 27th of May, at Epsom—that was the first time I had seen Hughes, but Brown I had seen for some years.

HUGHES—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Confined Six Months.

2242.
WILLIAM DOUGLAS was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of August, 2 trusses of hay, value 5s., the goods of
Thomas Chapman, his master.

THOMAS CHAPMAN . I am a cow-keeper, and live in Cheyne-street, Bedford-square—I have some premises in George-street, Euston-square, I keep hay and fodder there. In consequence of what I heard, I counted the trusses of bay, on the night of the 15th of August, and on going on the morning of the 16th I missed two trusses of meadow-hay—the prisoner had been in my service, and had gone out with his cart that morning—I pursued and overtook him near the seventh mile-stone—the policeman stopped him—I went to the cart, and found the two trusses of hay, which are mine—I send food for my horses in the nose-bags, but no hay.

GEORGE MOORE . I am a cow-man, in the prosecutor's employ. On Monday morning, the 16th of August, I saw the prisoner go to the hay
loft, take two trusses of hay, and put them into his cart—he went on to Edgeware—I told my master and the policeman of it.

Prisoner. I put them out of the loft, and he put them up to me. Wit
ness. No, I did not.

THOMAS BOYCE (police-constable S 204,) I went after the cart, at half-past five o'clock that morning, and overtook the prisoner at Edge-ware, and after some distance, I asked him where he was going—he said, "After some green clover"—I said, "Perhaps you will give me a lift"—he said, "Yes, jump up"—I saw in the cart two trusses of hay—I went on with him to the Welsh Harp public-house, where I expected he would have parted with them, but he did not—I then got out, and followed him on—the prosecutor came up, and gave him into custody—I asked how he came by the hay—he said he did not know, but he had been riding on them for two miles.

GUILTY . Aged 37.—
Confined Six Months.

2243.
JOSEPH WALTER was indicted
for embezzlement.

THEODORE MONROE . I live in Harley-street. I am the honorary se
cretary of the Metropolitan Convalescent Institution, and am a subscriber to it. In September last I was the only secretary to the institution—the prisoner came into the service of the institution about May, 1840—he was to canvas, and collect subscriptions and donations—he was not to keep any subscription or donation longer than a fortnight, and if it amounted to

20l. or 30l. he was to pay it in immediately—he was paid by a per cent
age—he never accounted to me for a subscription from Maria Burrows.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. What are you? A. I am in no profession—I am studying, and live with my father—the management of this institution was in a great measure left to me—I was not of age when I first belonged to it—the prisoner accounted to me sometimes at my father's house, and sometimes he had to follow me to the hospital—I had regular books, but I did not take them with me to the hospital—he did not account to any body but me—Dr. Bell belongs to the institution—I left town I think about the last week in July, 1840, and returned about the 26th or 27th of September—I have never, to my knowledge, asked the prisoner about subscriptions which he had accounted for.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. When was it you entertained any doubt about his integrity? A. About the beginning of January—I cannot recollect ask
ing him about any subscription previous to that time.

MARIA BURROWS . I am a widow, and live in Albany-street, Regent's-park. On the 30th of September last I paid a guinea to the Metropolitan. Convalescent Institution—I handed it to my servant Dinah Philpott, to give to the person—this is the receipt—it is all written.

DINAH PHILPOTT . I am servant to Mrs. Burrows. On the 30th of September last the prisoner called for a subscription to this institution—I told my mistress, and she gave me a guinea, which I gave him—he wrote this receipt for it—(read.)

DR. WILLIAM BELL . I am a physician, and live in Princes-street; Ha
nover-square—I am one of the committee of this institution, and a sub
scriber. The prisoner never accounted to me for a guinea received from Mrs. Burrows—he paid me the money he received during Mr. Monroe's absence, and I gave a faithful account of it to Mr. Monroe.

JURY to MR. MONROE. Q. Has the prisoner acted contrary to the in
structions of the committee in giving a written receipt? A. Yes—he had a book of printed receipts, with a margin—I do not remember any in
stance in which he retained money beyond a fortnight, and then paid it.
NOT GUILTY .—(See page 664.)

2244.
RICHARD TAYLOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of August, 1 pig, price 6l., the property of
Thomas Flight.

GEORGE FRANCIS . I live in Leicestershire. I brought a white sow from there on the 10th of August, and she was left at Mr. Flight's dairy at Islington—it was of a particular sort, and was going out to New South Wales for breeding—it was worth 6l.—I saw her safe on the 17th of Au
gust—I have since seen a carcass which I supposed to be the same, in New-gate
market—I have examined it, and have no doubt whatever about it being mine—there was a mark on the near ear.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. What was the mark? A. A bit cut out of the under side of the ear—I do not know that there is a more common way of marking pigs, but this was done in a different man
ner—it was laid upon a board, and cut out in a diamond form—I had no other mark but the peculiar symmetry of the pig—it was between a Chi
nese and another breed—I do not know how long that breed has been in the market—my father and I have bred them for fifty or sixty years—this pig was lost on the 18th of August—when I lost, it it had its hair on—I saw it again on the 25th—it was then exposed to the air, that might

make it look a little browner—it had been scalded, and its entrails taken out, and the head was taken off—I should think the head had been off a day or two—I did not try to put the head and carcass together.
GEORGE NICHOLLS . I am layer-keeper to Mr. Thomas Flight. I had the keeping of this sow—she broke out on Wednesday fortnight—I have seen the carcass—it is about the size of the one we lost.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you find that she had a notch in both ears? A. Yes.

JOHN HUNT . I saw a white sow wandering near Holloway
turnpike, on Wednesday fortnight—the prisoner said he would take it to Islington-pound —the policeman came up and told him to let it alone, and asked him who it belonged to—he said, "To a cow-dealer in the Liverpool-road"—I saw him take it on as far as Highbury-brewery—he drove it first on one side and then on the other.

WILLIAM PARFETT . On Wednesday fortnight I saw the prisoner in Ball's-pond-road, about half a mile from Mr. Flight's, driving a white sow towards Kingsland-road—it was a very particular kind of sow—it was all white—I cannot say that I had ever seen any of that breed—the sow dropped down twice—I have seen the dead sow—it was somewhat similar to the size of the one I saw the prisoner with.

ROBERT SHINGLES (police-constable N 104.) The boy Hunt gave me information that he had seen a man driving a sow—I took the prisoner, and asked if he knew any thing about the pig that was lost—he said he did not—I took him to the station—he gave his address at Pearson-street, Hackney-road—I went there and found the pig hanging up at the back of his house—I took it to the station—the same pig has been shown to the prosecutor, and he said he believed it was his.

Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner gave you his true address? A. Yes, in Nottingham-place, Pearson-street—he said he had some live pigs there, and I found some—I took the dead pig to Laycock's, and hung it up.
JOHN PEGG (police-sergeant N 19.) The prisoner was brought to the station—I asked him if he had any pigs—he said he had two.

PHEBE BAYLESS . I have known the prisoner two years, on and off, by his killing pigs for me—he bought a poor pig of me in July for 1l. 17s. 6d.—it was a black and white breed, and I slit her ear with a pen-knife—she had a black face and a little white round her eyes—she weighed about seven
teen stone—the head of the pig that was found was very much like the one I sold to the prisoner.

GEORGE FRANCIS
re-examined. My pig weighed about twenty stone, and the dead one weighed eighteen stone six pounds without the head.
Cross-examined. Q. What would it weigh with the head? A. Nearly twenty stone.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 56.—
Confined Four Months.

2245.
JOHN PORTER was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of August, 1 pair of boots, value 9s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas Steel.

WILLIAM COOK . I am shopman to Thomas Steel, who lives in the Strand. At half-past two o'clock in the afternoon, on the 16th of August, I was in the shop, and saw the prisoner take this pair of boots off a stand, inside the
door—I ran after him—he was stopped by a gentleman—I came up and took them from him.
Prisoner. A young man asked me to hold them—I heard a cry of "Stop thief," and he ran off. Witness. He begged me to let him off, and said he did it through distress.

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

2246.
VIOLET DRYSDALE was indicted
for stealing, on the 6th of August, 4 table-cloths, value 10l. 8s., the goods of
William Humphries, her master; to which she pleaded

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 37.—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p: Judgment Respited.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

div1.p:
2247.
GEORGE WARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of August, 1 scent-bottle, value 10s. 6d., the goods of
Henry Kebble.

HENRY KEBBLE . I keep a glass-shop in Bedford-street. On the 14th of August the prisoner came and asked for a smelling-bottle or scent-bottle—he was a stranger—I showed him a number—he said there was none would suit him; he would go to the lady and ask if she would allow me to make one for her; he would go and be back in a quarter of an hour—he left, and by his running across the road 1 had suspicion—I looked at the tray, and missed this smelling-bottle—on the Monday following my son found him in Charles-street, Middlesex Hospital—I am sure he is the person—the smelling-bottle was found at Mr. Denny's, in Oxford-street.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What is it worth? A. 10s. 6d.—to me it is worth 6s. 6d.—my son attends to the business occa
sionally—I had noticed this before on the same day—nothing particular attracted my attention to it—I handed it to the prisoner with the rest—I did not say I did not know any thing about it till I had asked my son—I asked my son whether he had moved any bottles—this has no stopper—I am aware mine had no stopper—the prisoner was in the shop five or six minutes—he crossed the road—when he got to the other side he ran—I did not pursue—I said I missed the bottle before it was brought to me—directly the prisoner was gone I said, "This boy has boned a bottle"—I pointed out the fellow one to this—I said I had seen it before the prisoner came in—I am quite certain about it—I bought this bottle in October, 1839—I gave 6s. 6d. for it—it has been in the shop—it might have been in the window half a dozen times—other persons besides myself sell bottles.
COURT. Q. Is this a scent-bottle? A. Yes, it is—immediately he was gone I cast my eye on the tray, and it was gone.

HENRY HAMILTON . I am in the employ of Mr. Denny, a jeweller and hardwareman. On the 14th of August the prisoner came, with this smell
ing-bottle, and left it to be repaired—the top was off and was bruised—it would be more valuable when repaired than unrepaired.

Cross-examined. Q. What value do you attach to it at present? A. They are about two guineas a dozen—two years ago they were worth more—I gave 1s. 6d. for it after it was repaired, and it was 6d. for repairing it—it might perhaps fetch 3s. 6d.—I do not think it would be worth 10s. 6d.—
when the prisoner came in he desired it to be repaired—he wanted a stick in exchange for it, and I said I would give him 1s. 6d.
COURT. Q. If you did not think it worth 1s. 6d., you would not have given it? A. No.

ARTHUR GORE (police-constable D 199, examined by MR. BALLAN
TINE.) Q. Had not the prisoner told you where to find this? A. On his first examination no bottle was produced, and the Magistrate expressed a desire to discharge him—the prisoner said he had such a thing, and said where it was to be found—without that I should have had no clue to it.
COURT. Q. When did you take the prisoner? A. On the 16th—he was taken to Marylebone station—the prosecutor's son stated why he was taken—the prisoner then denied having taken the bottle.

CATHERINE SMITH . I am in the habit of making door-mats, and hawk
ing them about—I have to walk about the street a great deal—I live in George-alley, Union-court, Holborn. On Saturday fortnight, as I was walking about, I found a smelling-bottle—it was the colour of this smell
ing-bottle at any rate—I afterwards saw the prisoner go into a smelling. bottle shop, and I thought he might want one—he ran pretty quickly out of the shop, and round the corner—I thought I should not meet him, but I did afterwards—I offered him the smelling-bottle, and he bought it for 1s.,—it was a bottle of this description.

COURT. Q. Did you ever find a smelling-bottle before? A. No—I do not know the owner of the shop who lost the bottle—I saw the prisoner run out smartly—he asked me my name, and where I lived—I told him—I never heard that this was lost out of a gentleman's shop, till a gentleman and lady came to me last Friday.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

p.rs:
GUILTY. Aged 17
—Recommended to mercy by the Prosecutor.

div1.p: Confined Three Months.

2248.
JAMES YOUNG was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of August, 2lbs. weight of copper, value 10d., the goods of
Henry Bris
towe, in a vessel in a port of entry and discharge.—2nd COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
John Wilt and others.

JOHN BOYCE . I am a gate-keeper at the London Docks. On the 12th of August I stopped the prisoner coming out of the gate—I suspected all was not right, and asked what he had got—he said, "Nothing"—I said, "I think you have, come to the box," and from his stomach, next his skin, I took these 21bs. weight of copper—he had been employed working on board the John King—John Wilt and others are the owners, and Henry Bristowe is the master—it was in a port of entry and discharge.
Prisoner. I was in liquor. I have a wife and six children; they are starving. Witness. He had 3s. 6d. a day.
HENRY BRISTOWE . I am master of that vessel, and the contents of it are under my care—this copper came from there.

GUILTY . Aged 39.—
Confined Four Months.

2249.
MARY M'DERMOTT was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of August, 1 waistcoat, value 1l.; 1 shilling, and 2 sixpences: the pro
perty of
Mosts Cox; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

MOSES COX . I am in the service of Johnson and Webb; they are brewers, in Bowl-yard. On the 14th of August, between one and two o'clock in the morning, I fell in with the prisoner—I asked her if she knew of a lodging-house, and she took me to No. 10, Church-street—lam mar
ried, but I could not get in at my lodgings—the prisoner went to bed with me—I gave her a shilling, and paid for the bed—I undressed and went to bed—I had a shilling, two sixpences, and two or three halfpence in my trowsers' pocket—I had a waistcoat, and that I put on the box—I did not go to sleep—I was not in bed above three quarters of an hour when the prisoner got up—she put on her gown and shawl, went to my pocket, took my money, and my waistcoat as well—I saw her just going out of the door and called to her, but she went off—I saw her on the Sunday evening following in Broad-street—I accused her of robbing me—she said she knew nothing of me, and had not been in the house—the waistcoat pro
duced is mine.
Prisoner. You gave me 1s. 9d., and said you bad no more money—I told you I was not going to stay with you for that, and then we came down stairs.

GEORGE JOHN RESTIEAUX . I am a policeman. On Sunday night I re
ceived the prisoner from the prosecutor—she told him if he would give her 4s. she would give him the waistcoat—he refused—I took her to the station—she then said, if he would forgive her she would give the waistcoat—she then said it was at Biddy Ryan's—I went there, and found it between the sacking and the bed.
Prisoner. I said, if he would give me the rest of the 4s. that he said he would give me, I would get it him; he took me to a house, and sent for a pot of porter, and sent the boy for a policeman.

ANN CLARK . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former convic
tion, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—I searched the prisoner at that time, and was present at her trial—she is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Fourteen Years.

2250.
ELIZABETH DUNKS was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of August, 1 shirt, value 3s.; 2 sheets, value 5s.; and 1 apron, value 1s.; the goods of
John Constantine Lombardy; and that she had been before convicted of felony.

DOROTHY LOMBARDY . I am the wife of John Constantine Lombardy—we live in Ray-street. I have known the prisoner some years—she acted as my servant off and on—I left home on the 4th of August, and returned on the 14th—the prisoner was in and out at my place during that time— when I returned I missed the articles stated—the prisoner was at her own lodging—I suspected her, and I gave notice to the officer—he found this shirt and two sheets of mine—this is all I have got.
WILLIAM ALEXANDER CHAPMAN . I am a pawnbroker, and live in Clerkenwell. I have a shirt and two sheets—they were pawned with me, but not by the prisoner—this is the duplicate of them.

CHARLES ELLIOTT (police-constable G 132.) I beard of this, and saw the prisoner coming down Turnmill-street on the 18th of August—I told her I wanted her for a robbery in Ray-street—she said she did not do it—the next day she said she was induced by another girl to steal the property, and gave it to her to pledge—I found the duplicate on the prisoner, and the articles are pawned in her name.
Prisoner. I did not pawn them, nor take them; it was another person; the duplicate was not found on me.
WILLIAM GRAY (police-sergeant G 12.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2251.
JOHN BURTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of Au
gust, 4 sovereigns and 2 half-sovereigns, the moneys of
Ruth Dring.

FRANCIS DRING . I live at Limehouse, and am in the milk line. The prisoner lived five months with me—he had to go about with milk—I left him at home, on the 15th of August, to mind the house while I went to chapel.

RUTH DRING . I am the daughter of Francis Dring. On the 15th of August the prisoner was at home—I had a drawer, in which I had the money stated—it was safe on the Thursday before—there were four sovereigns, two half-sovereigns, and 15s. 6d. in silver—I missed the gold—the silver was not taken—I suspected the prisoner, and asked him whether he had been to my drawer—he said no, he had not—I told the policeman—some of the money has been found, and the prisoner owned to it at the station.
Prisoner. They frightened me; I did not know what I was saying.

DANIEL DONOVAN (police-constable K 319.) The prosecutrix told me of this—I asked the prisoner about it—he said he knew nothing of it—I took him to the station, and found on him a key and a sixpence—I went to his master's, and found the key would not fit the drawer that the money was taken from.

CHARLES WHITE (police-constable K 259.) I was in the station—the prisoner said, "I have taken the money; three sovereigns are in my box, and two I have spent"—I then went to No. 4, Waterloo-street, broke a box open, and found three sovereigns in it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Three Months.

2252.
WILLIAM DE LACY was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of July, 1 plane, value 4s.; 1 saw, value 3s.,; 1 square, value 2s. 6d.; and 1 bevil, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
Robert Cox; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

ROBERT COX . I am a carpenter, and work for Mr. Archbutt, of Sloane-street —his shop is in Pelham-place, Brompton. I and some of my fellow workmen left some tools there on the 22nd of July—I locked the door and bolted the windows, and left at seven o'clock in the evening—the next morning, at half-past six, I found some person had got in—I missed the tools stated in the indictment—these produced are them—four of the other men lost tools also.

JOSEPH BAKER . I am a policeman. On the morning of the 23rd of July I fell in with the prisoner about a quarter of a mile from the work-shop, at a quarter-past four o'clock—he was carrying a basket full of tools—he asked me which was the way to Piccadilly, and said he was going to work—he had an apron tied round him like a carpenter, and had a Petersham coat on—I took him, and found these tools.
WILLIAM WALLIS (police-constable E 64.) I produce a certificate of
the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office— (read)—the prisoner is the man.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2253.
WILLIAM NEWBERRY was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of August, 1 pocket-book, value 1s., and an order for the payment of 6l. 2s. 6d.; the property of
William Lassiter.

WILLIAM LASSITER . I am porter to Mr. Leslie, a coach auctioneer. On the 9th of August there was a sale going on in Worship-street—I put my coat into a cupboard there, about nine o'clock in the morning—the cupboard had no lock—about four in the afternoon I missed my pocket-book and a cheque from the pocket—I sent a man to stop the cheque—I have never found the hook—this is the cheque for 6l. 2s. 6d.—it was drawn by Mr. Leslie's son.

GEORGE BOLTON . I keep a coffee-house. The prisoner lodged with me for thirteen nights—I asked him, on the 6th of August, for the pay
ment of his lodging, and on the Monday, the 9th, he produced this cheque from a pocket-book similar to what the prosecutor says he lost—he asked me if I could give him the difference—I said I had not got it, hut I would give it him in the morning—the next morning I went to the banker's, and they told me the cheque was stopped, having been stolen the day before—I went home—the prisoner did not come again till the 16th, and then I had him taken.
EDWARD BARKER (police-constable E 124.) I was called to take the prisoner—he said he picked up the cheque in Newgate-street.
Prisoner. I picked it up in Newgate-street.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Six Months.

2254.
JOHN HARRIS was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of August, 46 yards of fustian, value 2l. 10s., the goods of
Benjamin Parnham.

JOHN LACK . On the 20th of August I saw the prisoner in company with another person—the prisoner had the fustian on his shoulder—the prosecutrix came running after them—the prisoner and the other boy ran round Wellclose-square together—the prisoner carried the fustian till they got to Neptune-street, and then gave it to the other—a carman found it.

CATHERINE PARNHAM . I am the wife of Benjamin Parnham—we keep an outfitting-warehouse for seamen, in Grace's-alley, Well-street. This fustian is our property—I saw the prisoner go out of our shop, with the fustian on his shoulders—I followed him and the other to the middle of Wellclose-square—I then returned and called my sister to mind my shop—I then went to the corner of Norton
passage—there was a crowd there, and a carman went up a passage, and brought this fustian to me—the prisoner was not taken till last Thursday.

GUILTY .* Aged 18—
Transported for Seven Years.

2255.
MARY BERRY was indicted
for stealing, on the 3rd of August, 1 kettle, value 10s., the goods of
George Daw.

GEORGE DAW . I am a pastry-cook, and live in Great Marylebone-street. The prisoner used to come charing at our house—some time ago I missed a new kettle—I suspected her, and found it at the pawn
broker's—this now produced is it.
GEORGE ROGERS (police-constable D 71.) I took the prisoner, and found the kettle.
HENRY WINCH . I am a pawnbroker. I produce this kettle—it was pawned by the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor's wife gave me time to get some things out, which I pawned; I had forgotten this; if they had given me longer time I should have thought of this.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 45.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined Eight Days.

2256.
ROBERT WILKINSON was indicted
for feloniously receiving of an evil-disposed person, on the 24th of July, 1 wooden box, value 6d.; and 289 yards of ribbon, value 5l. 2s.; the goods of
Daniel Stubbs; well knowing them to have been stolen.

DANIEL STUBBS . I am a linen-draper and haberdasher, and live in Church-street, Hackney. On Friday, the 16th of July, I had some boxes of ribbon on the counter—there was a blue box of ribbon, and also a white one—there was a common sort of ribbon in the blue box, which was soiled, remnants and short lengths—in the white box there was this description of ribbon now produced—a great many of them had never been cut, but some were shorter lengths—I was in the shop early on the morning of the 17th, when two men came in—I did not see the ribbons in the morning—I did not notice the boxes—the ribbons were missed on that Saturday—on the following Saturday I was passing along Shoreditch, and in the pri
soner's shop window I saw a blue box full of ribbons, which I recognised as mine—I called a policeman, and we went into the shop—I saw the pri
soner there, and asked to look at the ribbons in the window—he showed me two boxes of ribbons, before I asked to see the blue one—when he produced that, I took up one of the pieces, looked at it, and found my private mark on the card, inside the ribbon, partly erased—I told the pri
soner they were my ribbons, and asked where he bought them—he said he bought them of Cheaper and Co., of Wood-street, three months before, and he could show the invoice—he went and fetched some invoices—the policeman looked over part of them, but could not find any invoice to answer to that—I did not notice the date of them—he was then given into custody—the policeman took possession of the blue box and ribbons—this produced is it—a few days after the prisoner had been taken the policeman showed me some other ribbons, among which I recognised some of mine.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How soon after the first lot was found did you see the second? A. I do not know to a day, it was two or three days—the box was in the prisoner's window, as well as the ribbons exposed for sale—any one passing could see them—I did not look over the invoices myself at that time—I did a few days afterwards, when the pri
soner was in custody.
MR. CHAMBLRS. Q. Who showed you the invoices when you looked
over them a few days afterwards? A. The prisoner's wife—I did not see any thing at all then—I did not stop above a few minutes in the house.

SAMUEL STUBBS . I am the prosecutor's son. I was in the shop on Saturday, the 17th July, when two men came in—one of them went away rather abruptly, and I afterwards missed two boxes of ribbon—I have looked at the ribbons produced, and they are all my father's—I covered this box myself—after the prisoner was in custody, I went to his house with the officer and found about five pieces more of my father's ribbon—they were the same pattern as those we lost—I do not find any of my father's marks on these five pieces—I only judge from the pattern—they are worth about 15s.

THOMAS PARKER . I am in the house of Cheaper and Co., Wood-street, Cheapside—they used to serve the prisoner with ribbons. I only know from our books when we last supplied the prisoner with ribbons—I have the day-book here in which the goods are entered—we have a ledger as well, in which we book the amount of the different entries—the first entry is made in the day-book.
MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is that in your handwriting? A. No, but my name is at the bottom as having given the parcel in.
MR. CHAMBERS. Q. When was the last time you sold him ribbons? A. On the 21st of April, 1840.

Cross-examined. Q. I dare say yon will undertake to swear that there were no ribbons sold to him since 1840? A. I will—there are about three of us who sell ribbons—this book is finished—there is another book suc
