ceeding this, but that is not here—this book goes down to May, 1841—we are still carrying on business.

MR. CHAMBERS. Q. Have you searched through the other book? A. No, because we have not done any business with the prisoner since 1840, I know that of my own knowledge—the other book begins with 1841—we discontinued our account with the prisoner in 1840, and have not done any further business—ours is a wholesale-house—three of us manage the business, Mr. Jackson, Mr. Arnold, and myself—I see most of the goods that go out—I can fetch the other book.

WILLIAM HOLLAND . I am a policeman. I went into the prisoner's shop with the prosecutor and another officer—some ribbons were shown to the prosecutor—the prisoner produced a file of invoices—I looked them over—I did not take them away—the prisoner said be had bought those ribbons of Cheaper and Co., 36, Wood-street, Cheapside, some months ago—I turned round to the prosecutor, and said, "This is a serious charge to make against an apparently respectable man, look at your ribbons again, and be satisfied beyond the possibility of all doubt, and be sure they are your a"—he looked again and said, "I am sure they are mine, they were in my shop a few days ago, my son papered the box, and previous to being papered with blue there was grey paper"—I looked, and there was grey paper under
neath.

HENRY WILLIAM DUBOIS . I am a policeman. I went to the prisoner's shop after he was in custody, and found five pieces of ribbon in one of the drawers behind the counter, which the prosecutor has seen—Hayward, a constable, was there at the time—the prosecutor's son recognized them.

DANIEL STUBBS
re-examined. All the ribbons in this box are mine—they are not packed as they were when they were lost—there were more in quantity than are here, and some were in a different box.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Did yon not see some of your ribbons in another shop window? A. No—I saw the same patterns in one or two win. dows—I did not go in—the prisoner's shop is about two miles from mine—he lives in Shoreditch—the ribbons were all lost the same day—most of them were in the white box, which is not here—here are one or two pieces in this box which were in it when lost—the others were not found.

WILLIAM HOLLAND
re-examined I took away a large quantity of pro
perty from the shop in the first instance, which was not claimed—I took away 580 rolls of ribbon, and left about 2000 rolls behind—those produced formed a very small portion of the stock—the prisoner and his wife and a little boy served in the shop—the business was not on a very small scale.

HENRY WILLIAM DUBOIS
re-examined. The prisoner, his wife, and a boy, were the only persons I saw in the shop—I took all the books away—I gave two up by application from counsel to the Magistrate—they were small books—the one I retained is not respecting this case—the other two were for entering goods, but I could not make out how they were kept—there was an account of ribbons and various other articles in them, but they were not regularly kept, and there were no dates.

THOMAS PARKER
re-examined. I have now brought the other book—there is no entry of any later dealing for ribbons—there are other transact
tions since—the last transaction is on the 11th of May, but then he did not buy any ribbons—he has not bought any ribbons since 1840—the last dealing for ribbons was on the 26th of April, 1840—the dealing ceased in May, 1840—there are no dealings entered in the new book at all—I have looked, and there are no dealings later than I have stated.
JURY. Q. Do you ever sell ribbons of different lengths and remnants? A. No—we always sell in half pieces.
NOT GUILTY .

2257.
ROBERT WILKINSON was again indicted
for feloniously re
ceiving of an evil-disposed person, on the 24th of July, 47 pots of oint
ment called nutritive cream, value 4l. 2s. 6d.; 36 pots of bear's grease, value 2l. 14s.; 10 bottles of balm of Columbia, value 1l.; 14 cakes of soap, value 9s. 4d.; 24 pots of pomatum, value 7s.; 3 boxes of tooth powder, value 6s. 4d.; 1lb. 14ozs. weight of pins, value 1s.; 1lb. weight of pomatum, value 2s.; and 6 pomatum pots, value 1s. 9d.; the goods of
Thomas Pickford and another, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

JOHN GOODMAN . I am in the employ of Messrs. Kennaby, wholesale perfumers, of Westmoreland buildings, Aldersgate-street. On the 24th of July I received an order from Mrs. Scott, of Barnsley, for a number of articles of perfumery—I packed them in a box on the 20th—I have a copy of the invoice which went with the goods—there were two dozen of Finne
gan's cream, at 3s. 6d.; two dozen ditto, at 2s. 6d.; three dozen of Atkinson's bear's grease, at 2s. 6d.; one dozen of balm of Columbia, and other articles—among the things now produced are two out of half a dozen of almond shaving cakes; ten out of a dozen balm of Columbia; one dozen and eleven out of two dozen half-size of Finnegan's cream; the whole of the 3s. 6d. size; three out of one dozen of don to tooth-powder; and also some soap—the gross amount of the articles invoiced is 14l. 4s. 3d.—the invoiced price of the articles found is about 9l. 4s. 2d.—here are all the

dummy pots which were among the things sent—a number of articles have been produced to me by Hay ward the officer, which in every respect cor
respond with the articles I had put into the parcel—I know some of them by the mark on the outside wrapper—this "2s. 6d." is pat on by Mr. James Kennaby to distinguish the size—that is in precisely the same state as when we sent it out—here is one of the 3s. 6d. since, which is packed pre
cisely as it was when I sent it—after packing the articles I put on the address on the box, "Mrs. Scott, Barnsley, Yorkshire"—I then handed the box over to the porter, and directed him to take it to Mr. Pickford's.

JAMES LEWIS KENNABY . This parcel has my handwriting on it—I remember receiving the order for these goods, and calling it over with Mr. Goodman—I remember the packing up of the goods—I know the articles were contained in that package—Finnegan'a cream it an article not very easy to be had—there are but few agents in London for the tale of it—I know this particular article came from our shop—we have had but nine dozen of that size since we commenced dealing with Mr. Finnegan, and I know bow they have all been disposed of with the exception of this portion—all those I have sold went into the country, and none in London at all.
ALEXANDER HOWARD . On the 20th of July I took a package directed to Mrs. Scott, of Barnsley, to Messrs. Pickford's, at the Castle, in Wood-street.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Why do you call it Messrs. Pickford's? A. It is called so—I delivered the goods at the Castle inn to the person who signed my book—that is all I know.

JOHN AYRES . I am a checker off and porter at Messrs. Pickford's, at the Castle inn, in Wood-street. I received a box in the evening part of the 20th of July, and checked it on the delivery book—it was my business to take the box, and place it among the other goods to go to Barnsley, in Yorkshire, by railway—it would leave our place by wagon, which was to go to the Birmingham railway, where we have a warehouse.

WILLIAM HANDS . I am clerk at the Castle inn, in Wood-street—it is the concern of Thomas Pickford and Joseph Baxendale. I remember teeing a package there on the 20th of July, directed to Mrs. Scott, of Barnsley—I attended the loading of the wagon—it was loaded to go to the warehouse at the railway station, at Caraden-town—this package was placed on the wagon soon after it was weighed—I saw it weighed, and checked it off in my book.

Cross-examined. Q. Does Mr. Thomas Pickford interfere in the busi
ness at all? A. Yea—I believe he acts there—I know he is in the concern—I heard it from them that know—I have not seen him for some time—I cannot say how long—I cannot tell whether I have seen him within this twelve or eighteen months—I might have seen him within the three years—he is at Manchester—I do not know him, no further than by sight—I saw him once when he was in London—I should know him again if I saw him—he is not tall—he is rather stout—it was about fourteen months or two years ago that I saw him—he was then in the yard.
MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You have always been the clerk of Thomas Pickford and Joseph Baxendale? A. Yes—they pay me my wages.

GEORGE BASS . I am in the employ of Pickford and Co., and am guard to the wagons that go from Wood-street to Camden-town. On the 20th of July—I took the wagon away from the Castle inn to Cam
den-town, and saw it unloaded at the warehouse—I do not know whether.
the parcel in question was on the wagon or not—whatever was in the wagon I took to Camden-town—it was not my business to make the way bill—it was Eyre's business to load the wagon.
Cross-examined. Q. When did you see Mr. Pickford? A. I never saw him in my life.
THOMAS PARSONS . It is my place to check the goods that arrive it Pickford's warehouse, at Camden-town station, by the wagon from Wood-street—I am in the employ of Messrs. Pickford and Baxendale.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you ever see Mr. Pickford? A. Yes, about eighteen months ago, but not at all since—lam not aware that he has been in London since—I saw him then in Camden-town in a gig with Mr. Bax-endale—I had never seen him before—I was told it was Mr. Pickford by his servants, who have known him for many years—he was a tallish man—he was not old or young—I cannot exactly tell the size of a man sitting in a gig—I have known the firm for these twenty years, and always knew it to go by the name of Pickford and Co.
MARY ANN SCOTT . I live at Barnsley. I gave an order for a quantity of perfumery to Messrs. Kennaby—I never received the goods according to that order.

WILLIAM HOLLAND . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody on Saturday, the 24th of July—when the prisoner was in custody, I and Hay ward went to his house—we had left Fisher, an officer, in the house when we first took the prisoner, and when we returned I saw Hay-ward find, in the parlour, on the left hand side of the door, seventy-three packages, consisting of those now produced—I also saw Hayward bring down twenty-eight more from up stairs, but did not see him find them.

JAMES HAYWARD . I am a policeman. I went back, after the prisoner was in custody, and found Fisher in possession there—I searched the bouse in company with Holland—in the attic, at the top of the house, I found twenty-eight pots of pomatum laid in a large empty box, with some straw at the bottom—the box had no lid to it—I then went down into the parlour at the back of the shop, and on the left-hand side of the door I found seventy-three more packages of perfumery, covered with a hand
kerchief—I took all the articles to the station, and have now produced them—they—have been seen by Mr. Goodman and Mr. Kennaby.

THOMAS FISHER . I am a policeman. I was left in charge of the pre
mises from the time the prisoner was taken into custody by Holland till they were afterwards searched in my presence by Holland and Hayward, when the prisoner was in custody—I know where these things were found in the parlour—nothing was done with those articles after the prisoner was taken into custody—no one had access to that part of the premises while I was there—they must have been in the same position as when he left—I saw a parcel in the corner, with a handkerchief covered over them, when I first went in, and it afterwards turned out to be the seventy-three articles of perfumery.
Cross-examined. Q. He had been taken away in custody? A. Yes and I remained behind till the officers returned—I was only there about an hour.
HENRY WILLIAM DUBOIS . I am a policeman. I found this book lying on the window-ledge in the parlour at the back of the shop—among numerous other entries there is an entry of "Job of scents 5l."
Cross-examined. Q. A great many of the other entries are in pencil?

A. A good many—there is no other entry in ink but that, in that page, only the entry in the cash balance—here is another entry in ink on an
other folio, "Three dozen sticks," and that is the only other one in ink; all the others are in pencil—I took two other books away—the pri
soner was in custody at the time—ink marks are much more difficult to rub out than pencil.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. There is a mode of tearing them all off toge
ther? A. Certainly, or scratching out with a knife; but I see no erasure here, nor any marks rubbed out—the prisoner was apprehended on the 24th—I found this book on the 26th.
DANIEL BAILEY . I am in the employ of Messrs. Thomas Pickford and Joseph Baxendale. They are the carriers from the Castle inn, in Wood-street, to the station at Camden-town.
Cross-examined. Q. When did you see Mr. Pickford? A. About six months ago—I saw him on our premises then—I have been in the employ ever since—I will not swear I have seen him since.
COURT. Q. You have no reason to suppose he has turned over his business to any one else? A. Not the slightest.

(Henry Bakewell, Church-street, Shoreditch; Charles Theodore Cur
ley, warehouseman to Williams and Mottram, Wood-street; and Samuel Rolfe, tailor and draper; deposed to the prisoner's good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 34.—
Transported for Ten Yean.

2258.
JOHN JAMES was indicted
for stealing, on the 27th of August, 1 packing-case, value 7s.; 6 glass bottles, value it. 6d.; and 6 quarts of wine, value 12.; the goods of
John Rockley, his master.

JOHN ROCKLEY. I am a wine-merchant, and keep the New Hummums, hotel, Covent-garden; the prisoner was three or four months in my ser
vice, and boarded in the house. On Friday, the 27th of August, I went to the police-station at Bow-street, in consequence of information I re
ceived, and there saw a case and some bottles of wine, in consequence of which I gave the prisoner into custody—I can speak to the wine, it being sealed with my name, and the case.

THOMAS ELLIS . I am an oyster-dealer, and live in Bedford-court, Covent-garden. On the 29th of August the prisoner left a box at my door, and I took it in charge—he told me he would bring a horse and cart and take it away, but he did not, and I gave it up to the police—this is the case, I can swear it.
RICHARD GABRIEL GABB . I am a police-sergeant I went to Ellis's shop—he delivered me a case containing this wine, as it does now—I found Mr. Rockley's name on one of the seals.

ALLEN PHILLIPS . I am a policeman. I went to Mr. Rockley's on the 27th, and heard a conversation between the prisoner and Mr. Rockley—the prisoner said "Have mercy on me, master; do not give me into custody"—Mr. Rockley gave him in charge, and on the road to the sta
tion, he said he took the wine to send to his wife, for her to make a little money, as she was very badly off and ill in the country—I found two direc
tions on him—they are directions to his wife—I told him what he said I should give in evidence.

Prisoner. The wine I had from a person who used to live at Liverpool with a Mr. Hanson, he is now agent for somebody—he owed me 30s., and said he would give me the wine for it—it was never on Mr. Rockley's pre
mises,
but the case I took from Mr. Rockley intending to return it—I sealed the cork with Mr. Rockley's seal for my wife to know where I lived.

MR. ROCKLEY re-examined. Some of this wine is Lisbon, which he bottled in my cellar the day before—he had the care of the seal, and of the cellars—I am certain these formed part of my stock—this Hock I know—I have no question but this case was secreted to take out next morning while I was at breakfast.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2259.
HENRY JARVIS was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

2260.
JOHN WATSON was indicted
for assaulting
Robert Tomkins, with intent, &c.

GUILTY . Aged.—
Confined One Year.

2261.
EDWARD JONES was indicted
for an indecent assault
NOT GUILTY .

2262.
JOHN HEATH was indicted
for assaulting
James Kirkman, with intent, &c.

GUILTY . Aged 44.—
Confined One Year.

p.hi: Sixth Jury, before Mr. Common Sergeant.

div1.p:
2263.
DANIEL DAVIES was indicted
for assaulting
Sarah Green, with intent, &c.

GUILTY . Aged 67.—
Confined Nine Months.

2264.
JOSEPH WALTER was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

MARIA BURROWS . I am a widow, living in Albany-street, Regent's-park, I am subscriber to the Metropolitan Convalescent Institution—last Sep
tember I paid the prisoner my subscription for that year—on the 9th of July, my servant, Dinah, came to me for another subscription for this year—I went with her into the dining-room—I saw the prisoner—he said he called for the subscription to the Metropolitan Convalescent Insti
tution—I said it was a very short year—he looked at something, and said it was within a day, either before or after the time that I had paid the sub
scription last year—I offered him a 5l. note, which he could not change—I borrowed a sovereign of Dinah—I added 1s., and gave it him—he wrote this receipt (read)—I looked next day to my former receipt, and I found the last was paid in September—if I had known the prisoner had been dis
charged, and was not a collector of subscriptions, I should not have paid him the guinea in July.

DINAH PHILPOTT . On Friday, the 9th of July, the prisoner came—he said he had called from the Metropolitan Convalescent Institution for Mrs. Burrows' subscription—I went to my mistress—she sent me down for a card or paper—I lent my mistress a sovereign—she paid it him—the prisoner gave me a printed paper, which I gave him again.

THEODORE MUNRO . I am honorary secretary to the Metropolitan Con
valescent

Institution. I live in Harley-street—the prisoner was discharged from being a collector to the institution in March or April this year—he was collector before that—Mr. Linny was appointed in the prisoner's stead—the prisoner has not paid this guinea to the society, nor had he any autho
rity to receive it, as he had ceased to be a collector of subscriptions.

Cross-examined by MR. ESPINASSE. Q. Is Mr. Linny here to-day? A. Yes—I do not think Linny employed the prisoner to collect subscrip
tions—I believe Linny did employ him for something.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 31.—
Transported for Seven Years.
(See page 650.)

2265.
JOHN MAYES was indicted
for an indecent assault.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Three Months.

2266.
JOHN MORGAN was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

WILLIAM SANKEY . I am in the service of Mr. Chancellor, as an omnibus driver from Kensington to Whitechapel. I became acquainted with the pri
soner about eighteen months ago—he was in the habit of riding up and down, and sitting by me on the box—I said to him, I should like to buy an omnibus—I had a little money in the Bank—he came to me on the 28th of October—he rode down to Kensington—he gave me half a dozen cards to distribute, and said he had taken a public-house at last, called the White Bear, at Ratcliff-cross—he had been looking for a business for some time—he came to me two days after, and said he wanted to speak to me—he said, "You have got a little money in the Bank; I have got 700l.; I want you to let me have your 100l. out of the Bank; I will deposit the lease of my house in your bands as secu
rity for it—he said he wanted it to purchase the lease of his house, that his brother and sister were in the house, and he had possession, and was going on Saturday to get the lease; he would procure the lease on Satur
day, and deposit it with me—I said, if he would deposit the lease in my hands as a security I would let him have it—I met him, and went to my broker, and sold out 100l. stock, and got 90l. in notes, six sovereigns, and six shillings—I walked down towards Whitechapel, and saw the prisoner, and gave him nine 10l. notes, six sovereigns, and fifteen shillings, in the presence of Mr. Collier—he was" outside the bar—I was induced to part with my money because he said be would bring me the lease up in the evening—I should not have parted with my money if be had not told me he had 700l., and was in possession of the house—I saw him again on the fallowing Wednesday—Mr. Thompson was with me—we went into a pub
lic-house—we saw the prisoner there—I said, "You have got no public-house, where is my money?"—he said, "Do your best, and do your worst," and away he went—I could get no policeman to take him—my friend went and spoke to him—he said, "He may do his best, and do his worst, he shant have a d—d shilling"—I looked for him afterwards every day, and my answer was, he was gone into the country—I found him on the 22nd of last month—I saw him on the Sunday morning after I gave him the money—he said, "Sankey, I have not taken that house; come over the way to-morrow morning, to my uncle Tupcott's house, and I will give you the money"—I went, and saw his wife—she said he was gone into the country—I never could see any more of him.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Had you any money transaction with him before this? A. Never but once—I lent him 15l. I was to have had 20l., but eighteen of us sat down to supper—he had it Dearly three months—we were intimate nearly all that time—I did not know he had been a valet in the service of a nobleman—he always stated he had got plenty of property—I did not complain to him of the small interest I got in the funds—I went down to the White Bear public-house at Rat
cliff—I found he was in treaty for that house.

WILLIAM COLLIER . I went with the prosecutor to the Grapes public-house in October last—I saw him hand over to the prisoner nine 10l. notes, six sovereigns, and some silver—Sankey said to the prisoner, "You will let me have that lease"—he said, "Yes, certainly."

ANDREW THOMPSON . I was in company with the prosecutor in Octo
ber, at a public-house in Leman-street—some conversation took place with the prisoner and the prosecutor—I did not hear any thing they said—the prisoner called me on one side, and told me that Sankey had no witnesses, and therefore he would never pay him a single shilling, and he could not get a single shilling of it.

JOHN LUCKER . I have known the prisoner twelve months—he was a policeman, and then a gentleman's servant—he used to frequent the skit
tie-grounds very much—he did not appear to be a respectable person—I do not believe he is worth 700l.—he did not appear worth 300l.

Cross-examined. Q. What are you? A. The son of a deceased li
censed victualler—I am not in the habit of frequenting skittle-grounds.

THOMAS FAREY . I keep the White Bear public-house, Ratcliff-cross. I took it on the 25th of January last, from Charles Holben—he had it about six months—Holben was there in October—I do not know my thing about the prisoner keeping the house—when I took this house its valuation was 100l.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see any thing of the house in October? A. No—it was to draw four butts of beer a month—it was rather over
rated—the lease was 380l.—it was shut up when I took it.

ANDREW THOMPSON
re-examined. Q. I knew this house in October—the prisoner was not in possession.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2267.
WILLIAM READER was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

2268.
EDWARD HARRISON and
JAMES NEALE were indicted for
an indecent assault.

2269.
JOHN CLIFFORD was indicted
for a misdemeanor.

WILLIAM MOORE (police-constable N 226.) About a quarter before six o'clock, on the evening of the 9th of August, I was called to Pocoek's Fields, Islington—I found a great mob, and two men fighting—I took one of them into custody—the prisoner came and caught hold of me, and with the assistance of the mob got him from me—I pursued the man, and the prisoner came in front of me, and threw me down—I took him into custody, and was taking him to the station—he called to the mob not to let him go—they threw me down, dragged me into the field, and gave me se
veral blows—I got my truncheon out—the prisoner drew a knife, and cut
the cord which held my truncheon, and in cutting the cord he cut my wrist.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you see any knife in his band? A. Yes, and I saw him put his hand into his pocket—I stated that before the Magistrate—I do not know whether it was a prize fight—two respectable men were going by—they told me there was a fight—I was knocked down—I was rolled down on the field by the mob—they gave me several blows in the sides, with which I was laid up for six days—I can produce a certificate from the doctor that attended me—I went to the Magistrate on the day following—I did not take a boy into custody for a row, not for six days after.

Q. Did you ever state the mob were going to drown you? A. Yes, actually they were—I did not go to the Secretary of State to get them to prosecute nor to the Commissioners—I went into the ring, and took one of the men who were fighting—there was no row before that—I cried out, and a good while after I drew my staff—I took it out to use it—they cut the string, and took it off, and threw it out into the hedge—the pri
soner cried out to them to assist him to throw me into the water—it was the prisoner who threw me down.

WILLIAM FISHER . I was coming across the fields, and saw the con
stable come up and take one man—they hustled, and got him away—I saw the prisoner come up, catch hold of the constable by the waist, and be held him till the man got away—I did not see any blows struck.
WILLIAM WHITE . I saw the prisoner wrest the officer's staff away, and throw it over the hedge.

2270.
SAMUEL MIDGLEY was indicted
for an indecent assault, with intent, &c.
NOT GUILTY .

2271.
JOSEPH WALTON was indicted
for unlawfully, maliciously, and feloniously assaulting
Joseph Axon, on the 2nd of July, and stabbing and wounding him, in and upon the right thigh, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

JOSEPH AXON . I am a pork-butcher, and live at Romford, in Essex. On the 2nd of July I was at Fairlop fair—I was returning with my brother Thomas, about a quarter-past ten o'clock in the evening, and when we got about a quarter of a mile from the fair I saw a small party collected toge
ther, fighting—a person named Cutts was stripped, ready to fight—I spoke him, and after I spoke to him he went on fighting with the prisoner—they both fell, and when they were down the prisoner's wife came and kicked Cutts—I said it was unfair, and my brother went and took the pri
soner's wife away, picked the prisoner up, and afterwards picked up Cutts—the prisoner immediately came to me, and stabbed me twice in the back Part of my thigh, with some sharp instrument—I felt the blow, and felt

behind, and felt the blood in my trowsers—I had not interfered in the fight at all—I he stab did not disable me at the time—about five minutes after the prisoner stabbed me, he came to me and hit me with his fist in the forehead—my brother came up, laid hold of him, and I did so also—I let him go—I sent for Mr. Bowers, a surgeon at Romford, as soon as I got home—I was obliged to go to bed, and it was five or six weeks before I was able to do any kind of work—I was under the doctor's care about that time—I was confined to my bed seven or eight days.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have you dined to-day? A. That is my business—I have had my dinner, of course—I believe I have had a drop of porter—nothing else that I know of—I am quite sober—I had been in the fair about four or five hours, amusing myself—I had only been in one booth—my brother Thomas was with me—we had some bot
tled porter in the booth—I cannot say how much we had—it did me no harm—I left the booth sober—I cannot tell what we paid—I am certain I paid 1s., but whether I paid more, I cannot say—it was a joint pay
ment, a club—I will swear my share did not come to 2s.—I had my brother and sisters with me, and believe I paid more than most of them—I am not positive I did not pay 10s., or 50s.—I might have paid 20s.—I do not believe I did—I am quite sure I did not pay 10s.—nor 5s., but you speak to me in such a curious sort of way—my brother Thomas pulled the prisoner's wife away with his hands—he did not pull her petticoats up, to my knowledge—I will not swear about it—I saw him pull her away —I saw him catch hold of her shoulders, and pull her away—I will not swear he did not pull her petticoats up for the purpose of exposing her—I was looking on, and saw him pull her away quite decently—I do not know whether she was knocked down or not—I here were other people round—I saw my brother pull her away—whether she fell down, I cannot say—I did not see her petticoats pulled up—I will not swear they were not—there were people standing before me so as to prevent my seeing—I told my brother I was done for—I do not recollect saying "Pitch into him"—I will not swear I did not say so—I was acquainted with Cults—he was not one of the party drinking with us—I do not know how the quarrel arose—my brother had been in my company up to the quarrel, and did not know how it arose.

MR. RYLAND. Q. Were you perfectly sober when this took place? A. Yes.—I did not interfere with the prisoner's wife at all—I did not see her knocked down, or her clothes disturbed—it was rather a dark evening, and being in the forest, made it still darker.

THOMAS AXON . I was returning with my brother from Fairlop-fair—we were quite sober—I have known Cutts some time—I saw him in our way home, fighting with the prisoner—Cutts called out to me, "Halloo, Tom, is that you?"—I said, "Yes, Jem, is that you?"—they went on fighting, and both fell—I he prisoner's wife kicked Cutts as he laid on the ground, and I then interfered—I went to take the prisoner off from Cutts, and his wife struck me—I shoved her with my arm, and she fell—It might be with my shoving her back with my arm, I cannot say—she got up and struck me again—I did not ill-use her in any way—I saw the prisoner make two hits at my brother—I did not see any thing in his hand at the time—I laid hold of him, and so did my brother—my brother said something to me—I let go of the prisoner, and went to him—I ob
served that he had been stabbed in the thigh—his trowsers had a hole in
them, and blood likewise—I went for a doctor, who came and attended him—he was confined to his room eight or nine days—I saw the wound.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You were all very sober that night? A. Yes—I am a labourer, and work for my father at jobbing, or any thing—he is a pork-butcher, and keeps a shop at Romford—I serve in the shop but very little—I work in the field sometimes, and sometimes in the shop—I do not get my living at fairs and races—we had only been in one booth that night—I he Crown and Anchor—I know Cutts from living close by—he is a gardener—I did not hear Cutts say, "I want to fight, but the b—r won't let me"—my brother and I had had a bottle of porter together—my sisters were with us—we had three bottles between us all—I here were six or seven of us—my brother, my two sisters, Carter, a horse-dealer, and myself—I cannot tell who paid for the drink—I did not—I believe Carter did—he stood treat—we found the fight going on as we were returning from the fair—I went up to them as, I saw Cutts lying down, and the prisoner holding him by the throat—I did not say, "Pitch into him, the b—," nor did I hear it said—my brother did not say so—he never interfered at all—I did not hear Cutts say, "I want to fight, but the b—won't let me"—he was standing up when I went by, and he called to me—he was afraid of getting killed, I pose—I was taking a walk at the fair—I had no pea and thimble—the prisoner's wife was stand
ing alongside when Cutts called out to me—I went up to take the prisoner off Cutts—I did not pull his wife's petticoats over her head—I did not pull her petticoats up at all, nor meddle with her, only by shoving her away, as she was kicking Cutts—I did not take hold of her by her shoul
ders—that I swear—as I went to take the prisoner away she hit me, and I pushed her away—my arm came about her shoulder—I did not strike her with my fist—she fell—I did not take her by the shoulders before she fell—her petticoats did not go up at all.
MR. RYLAND. Q. Did you do anything indecent to her clothes or any thing? A. I did not—I did not go up to interfere till Cutts was on the ground.

JAMES BAILEY . I work as a gardener, at Romford. I was present and saw the best part of the fight between Cutts and the prisoner, and staid till it was over—after it was over I saw the prisoner go and strike Joseph Axon in the side two or three times, with a knife I pose, but I did not know it was a knife when he struck him—my brother John was there—I went up to the prisoner and asked if he had got a knife in his hand—he said, "Yes, and I mean to use it too"—I hat was after he had used it to the prosecutor—he had it in his hand—I did not see him put it any where—I saw the blade of a knife in his hand—that was about half a minute after I saw him strike Axon in the side—I afterwards saw Axon bleeding.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How far does Axon live from Fairlop-fair? A. Between three and four miles—he walked home—I had not been along with Axon in the fair.
COURT. Q. Did you notice when the prisoner's wife was thrown down? A. No, I did not—I saw her pulled away, and it was almost immediately after that I saw the prisoner strike Axon.

GUILTY. Aged 24.—Strongly recommended to mercy on account of the provocation. —
Confined Six Months.

2271.
JAMES DESHAY was indicted
for assaulting
George Hoare,
Joseph Benton, and
Thomas Samuel Bartlett, police-constables, in the ex
ecution of their duty.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

2273.
THOMAS GILBERT was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of August, 2 tame ducks, price 45.; the goods of
Thomas Dowling; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Six Days and
Whipped.

2274.
THOMAS WRIGHT was indicted
for stealing, on the 19th of August, 3 tame fowls, price 4s. 6d. the goods of
James Childs.

JAMES CHILDS . I live at Woodford. I lost three fowls—I did not miss them till the policeman took the prisoner with them—they had been kept in a pig-sty or shed, but the door was fast—Ihe prisoner goes about horse-keeping.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. What are you? A. I am a fore
man on the trust road. I saw these fowls safe on the 18th—they were gone on the 19th, and I saw them again on the 20th.

THOMAS BARTLETT (police-constable K 286.) On the morning of the 20th of August, at four o'clock, I met the prisoner at Stratford—I took him—I found on him this pair of scissors, these eight snares, and the three fowls—the prosecutor identified the fowls—I these snares are to catch hares or rabbits.

GUILTY .* Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

2275.
ROBERT ROUNDING was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th of May, 1 shovel, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
William Blunt.
WILLIAM BLUNT . I lost my shovel on the 15th of May, about eight o'clock in the evening, out of Woodford-forest—I know the prisoner, but he was not working there.

Cross-examined by MR. DOANE. Q. When had you the shovel safe? A. On the 15th of May—I saw it again on the 18th—I was working as a labourer there—we are not in the habit of changing or bartering our shovels—I saw it on the 18th at Mr. Pearson's lodge, about three quarters of a mile from where I was at work.
JAMES FOSTER . I bought this shovel of the prisoner on the 15th of May.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you not think it very unusual for a man to sell you a shovel? A. There was nothing suspicious in it—I bought it in the high road—I paid 1s. 6d. for it.
BENJAMIN HURRELL . About eight o'clock in the evening, on the 15th of May, I saw the prisoner take the shovel and put it in a bush—I was with him—I wished him to put it back again.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he put it back? A. No—he told me he knew the party, and he would have a lark—he left it there.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY. Aged 19.—Recommended to mercy. —
Confined One Month.

2276.
ELLEN SAMPSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of March, 2 handkerchiefs, value 1s.; 1 shift, value 6d.; 1 apron, value 6d.; 3 yards of silk, value 4s.; and 1 pincushion, value 6d.; the goods of
Byham Laws, her master.

BYHAM LAWS . I live at Stratford. The prisoner was in my service occasionally—I misssed these two articles—I he prisoner had an opportu
nity of gettig them.
MARIA PERKS . I am the prosecutor's housekeeper. I know these articles are his—I he prisoner came to the house soccasionally.
GEORGE SMITH (police-constable K 38.) I produce these articles, which I found in a box, which the prisoner said was hers, except this shift.

Prisoner's Defence. I bought the two shifts myself, the silk to make myself a bonnet, and I bought the apron—I had no handkerchief in my box—my sister Kit has done it out of spite—she broke my box and pawned my gowns, and then she brought the policeman to search my box.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Nine Months.

2277.
MARY SAMPSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of March, 1 apron, value 6d.; and 1 pillow-case, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Byham Laws, her master.
MARIA PERKS . These articles are my master's, Mr. Byham Laws—I missed them, but I cannot tell when—the prisoner was his in-door servant.

GEORGE SMITH . I found the duplicates of some of this property on Ellen, and the duplicate of the pillow-case was in a box, which Mary Sampson said was hers—she said it was all through her sister, it was all spite—her sister had had a quarrel with Ellen, and that sister told me where Ellen lived.
EVE ISAACS . I produce the pillow-case, pawned by Ellen Sampson—I produce some other articles—I cannot say who pawned them.
Prisoner. The pillow-case ticket was the only thing found in my box.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Nine Months.

2278.
MARY PARKER was indicted
for feloniously uttering, on the 9th of March, at Lewisham, a forged acquittance and receipt for the sum of 17s. 9d., well knowing it to be forged, with intent to defraud
Julius Tate Bower:
also, for a like offence on same day; to both of which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Confined Two Years.

2279.
THOMAS GRANT was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of August, at Lewisham, 12 forks, value 12l., 29 spoons, value 16l. 10s., 2 ladles, value 3l.; and 4 knife-rests, value 10s.; the goods of
William Ab
bott, in his dwelling-house.

THOMAS BODDY . I am servant to William Abbott, of Meadow-croft, Sydenham, in the parish of Lewisham. On the 11th of August, I left the dining-room—I he table was prepared for dinner, and the plate-basket was by the side of the sideboard, with spoons and forks in it, and some on the table—I left the window a little up—it looks into the road—I left the room at three o'clock, and went out—I afterwards, in consequence of in
formation, went into the room, and missed the articles stated—I gave
information to the police, and have since seen the articles—they are worth above 5l.—I these produced are them.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. What is your master's name? A. William—he has no other name—I have been two years with him—his crest is on the articles.

REV. EDWARD KNIGHT MADDOCK . I was on a visit at Meadow-croft. On the afternoon of Wednesday, between five and six o'clock, the 11th of August, I met the prisoner near Mr. Abbott's—I here was a boy near him but not immediately by him—I noticed that the prisoner dropped two spoons, and took them up again—in consequence of what I observed, I went in the same direction as he went, and afterwards met him with the same lad—I asked the prisoner if I had not seen him just now at Mea-dow-croft—he said, "No," and I suffered him to go on then—and after going a few paces, he started off across the field, making a motion to the boy to run too—I hey ran in parallel lines, but one diverging from the other—I was alone—I met a painter, who joined me, and we saw the pri
soner in a hedge—I had not lost sight of him till I found him in the hedge—he was crouching down—after I came up, I was on one side of the hedge and the painter on the other, and he started up from the hedge and ran in a different direction, and I saw the painter scuffling with him—I afterwards pointed out the spot where he had been crouching down, to the officer.

Cross-examined. Q. Was he apprehended there? A. No, he got away from there—I first saw him between five and six o'clock, I think—he was about thirty yards from the prosecutor's house then, and I was going towards it—I did not turn round to follow him till I had been into the house where I was visiting—I met him again in about half an hour going up towards the Dartmouth Arms public-house, not in a direction for the prosecutor's house—I met him at first coming in a direction from the prosecutor's house—after I had made inquiry, I followed him in the same tract, and met him coming back—I said to him, "Did I see you?"but I had no doubt on the subject—I am quite certain he is the person who dropped the spoons—I wished for positive proof of his guilt—I did not know then that any plate was lost—I might pose he was going to match I plate for his master, who might be a jeweller.

JOHN BEGLE . I am a painter and glazier, and live at Sydenhara. On the 14th of August, I saw the prisoner running in a field, and Mr. Mad-dock running after him—I came up to him, he was then lying in a hedge, and rushed out upon me—he took something out of his pocket with his left-hand, which looked like a knife—I laid hold of him, but he got from me—he had his coat closed with his hands, and when he came out of to hedge he let go of his coat—I here appeared to be something in his coat—I did not see him taken—I know the spot where he was crouched down.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe the other party has not been taken? A. Not that I know—I he prisoner squared at me, when I came up, with one hand, and his other hand was in his left-hand trowsers pocket.

WILLIAM GLADWIN (police-constable R 122.) I produce some gravy spoons, dessert spoons, and forks, which I found in the hedge, within half a yard of where the Rev. Mr. Maddock pointed out, in a lane at Syden-ham, wrapped up in a handkerchief.
Cross-examined. Q. How far was it from where Mr. Maddock pointed
out? A. Close to it—Mr. Maddock showed me the place where he was found in the hedge—I did not show the spot to the last witness.

THOMAS CAMPBELL (police-constable R 140.) I produce four dessert spoons, a sauce ladle, and tea-spoon, which I found in the lane, through the hedge, in the same spot—I they had dropped through out of the hand
kerchief, as my brother-constable took it up.

RICHARD HOBBS (police-constable R 138.) I found the prisoner crouched down in a ditch in the corner of Stansbeard-lane—I collared him and pulled him out—he said he was sorry he had not been over the other side of the hedge, and then he should have been two or three miles off—I said, "It is a pity, then, but what you had been on the other side"—he said he was very sorry he had not, and what a parcel of d—fools we most all he to stand there waiting for him—I and my brother-constable took him to the station.

JURY. Q. Do you know where the plate was found,? A. Yes, I took him about a quarter of a mile from there—I he hedge runs all along there—the plate was found in one field, and he in the adjoining field.
Q. How could he get from one to the other? A. There is a cross hedge and a bean field on the other side—he must have gone over the hedge—I took him between six and seven o'clock.

ANN BURNETT . I live at Brockley Farm. On the 11th of August, I saw the prisoner in Eliza-place, two miles' from Sydenham, with a red parcel—I soon afterwards saw some persons running after him—he ran across the field, but I did not see him put the parcel into the hedge—I was visiting at Eliza-place at the time—I he parcel was in a handkerchief with red spots, such as the one produced.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you known him before? A. No, I am quite certain of him—he was standing about thirty-yards from me when I first saw him—I have not the least doubt of him.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2280.
LAZARUS ISAACS was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of August, 1 pair of trowsers, value 20s., the goods of
John Nicholas Harris; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

JOHN RIXON . I am a stationer, and live in Richard-street, Woolwich, right opposite Mr. Harris. On the 9th of August, I saw the prisoner at his shop-door—he went in, went to the other end of the shop, took the trowsers off a peg, rolled them up, put them into a basket which he had, and was returning with them, when I secured him—he was trying to push the trowsers out of the basket when I caught hold of him—I did not let Dim get out of the shop.

Prisoner. I went in to ask the lady if she wanted any lemons; the corner of the trowsers hung to my basket, which was on my shoulder, and fell down—I was going to pick them up, when the gentleman came over and gave me in charge. Witness. They did not fall down—he put them into his basket, and they were half out when I got hold of him—he was pro
fessing to sell lemons—he had the basket, under his arm hanging by a strap round his neck.
JOHN NICHOLAS HARRIS . I am a tailor, and live in Richard-street, Woolwich. These are my trowsers, they are worth 1l., and are nearly new.
JOHN WATERMAN (police-constable R 44.) The prisoner told me they hung to the corner of his basket.

WILLIAM PARRAMORE . I am a policeman. I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—I was present at his trial, and know him to be the person described in that certificate, though he was then tried by the name of Eleazer Levy—(read)—I have not seen him since then.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2281.
STEWART M'KOWN was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of July, 1 washing-board, value 1s., the goods of
George Cousins.

GEORGE COUSINS . I am a gunner in the Royal Artillery. Some few weeks ago I lost a washing-board and tea-kettle from a washhouse at the back of Artillery-place—I afterwards saw the washing-board at Saville's shop, on the 2nd of July—I hat now produced is it—I his case was not taken up by the regiment, on account of the prisoner's character.
JOHN SAVILLE . I am a broker, in Wellington-street, Woolwich, bought this washing-board of the prisoner for 6d.

JOHN THOROGOOD (police-constable R 189.) I took the prisoner into custody—I asked him whether he knew any thing of the property I pro
duced—he said he knew nothing of it—I asked if he would deny it if I brought a witness who bought the property of him—he said, if that was the case, it was all well and good.

Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor and the witness are related toge
ther, and it is a combined thing between them against me; he does not live six doors from me; it is not likely I should steal it, and sell it to a man that knew me.

JOHN SAVILLE
re-examined. I never knew the prisoner before—I am no acquaintance of Cousins.

GEORGE COUSINS
re-examined. He is a gunner in the regiment, the same as myself—he has a good-conduct stripe on his arm—I here has been no quarrel between us—he has been convicted twice in the regiment for theft—a man is entitled to a stripe if he is two years out of trouble—it is a long time since he was in trouble—I never knew him before this occur
rence—he belongs to the 9th battalion, and I to the first—the property was locked up in the washhouse—I he prisoner rented a room in the same house for a very short time—there is no one here from the regiment to give him a character—the officers are aware he is on trial—I had used this washing-board a week before—it was not thrown aside as if it was lumber—the prisoner's wife asked if we had got such a thing to lend her, and when we came to look for it it was gone—I here has been no quarrel be
tween his wife and mine—I he board was exposed for sale at Saville's which is not far from where I live—I know it by marks where I pulled the head off, and nailed it on again myself—I bought it in Woolwich.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 23.—Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury.

div1.p: Confined Ten Days.

2282.
EDWARD STUDD was indicted
for feloniously killing and slaying
Frances Studd.
ELIZABETH DALTON . I know the prisoner, and knew his wife, France Studd—Ihey lived in Old King-street. On the 25th of June, about two

o'clock, I saw them talking together—they appeared to be quarrelling—I was twenty or thirty yards from them—I saw the prisoner strike her with his shut fist on the left side of the head—she was standing on the pave
ment—she staggered a little, and then she fell on her side into the road—the prisoner walked away, leaving her there—she got up, and I and Mrs. Ires went up to her—I here was a little scratch just over her right temple, where she fell, and there might be one drip of blood—she complained of her head, where she fell—I he prisoner walked as far as the Rodney public-house—she got up, and went after him, and they were talking together again—I did not follow her, but stood looking after them—I saw her next on the Thursday following, seven days after, in Old King-street—she then appeared to be very ill, and was going to the doctor's—I cannot say whe
ther the prisoner was sober or not on the 25th of June—I had never seen him before—I saw him knock her down, and know him to be the roan—his lips were frothed—I did not take much notice of him—I looked at his wife, as I thought she was hurt—he only struck her once—Ihey were both standing still when I came towards them—I did not see him walk up to her—I was examined before the Magistrate—what I said was read over to me, and I signed it, and also what I said before the Coroner.

BRIDGET IVES . I am the wife of Isaac Ives, and the sister of Dalton. I know the prisoner, and have seen his wife twice. On the 25th of June I was with my sister, coming down King-street, and just before we got op
posite the King's Arms public-house I saw the prisoner and his wife stand
ing on the pavement—I saw him hit her on the left side of the head—she fell on her right side into the road—I had not heard them talking together before, but they seemed to be talking—she got up, and went to the other side of the road, and he walked in the middle—when they got about twenty yards, she went to him—he had only hit her once, but he made an offer to hit her then—she put her hand into her pocket, and he went into the Cheroot public-house—we went to where he knocked her down, and she showed us the mark where he had hit her in the head, and the scratch where she fell—I here is a pavement there—I saw her next Thursday coining from the doctor's—she looked very bad, and had her head bound up in a white cloth—I saw nothing more of the prisoner—I cannot say whe
ther he was sober or drunk.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You will not swear he was sober? A. No.
JURY. Q. Was his wife sober? A. Yes—I am sure of that.

WILLIAM ATKINS . I am a surgeon. On the 26th of June the deceased came to me—I had known her for a few months, but had not attended her before—she complained of violent pains in her head—I examined it, but could perceive no external cause for it—she did not point to any part of her head—I gave her medicine, treating it as a common pain in the head, which frequently occurs—she came again on the 27th, and said she thought herself rather better—she came again on the 28th, and stated she was much the same—I saw her again on Wednesday the 30th, when I was requested to visit her—I found her considerably worse, and in bed—I ordered mus
tard plasters to various parts of the body, treating it as a case of inflamma
tion, and ordered leeches to the temple on account of the inflammation—there were no external marks of inflammation—she appeared in violent pain all over the head—she was not exactly sensible—she was not coma
tose—there was a wandering state of mind—I saw her again the first

thing oh Thursday morning, the 1st of July—she was then much worse—she died on Saturday evening, the 3rd—I opened her head on Monday and found very extensive inflammation—I he sinuses of the brain filled with serous fluid, and the whole of the brain having marks of extensive inflammation—I found no external bruise, except a little scar on the left temple, which might have happened months before, for it was perfectly healed—my opinion is, from the history of the case during the time I treated it, that her death was caused from a blow received—I attribute her death to inflammation of the brain—I did not find any local injury within the skull—she was in a very emaciated state.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Might not the inflammation you have stated be as well occasioned by hitting against the curb
stone, if she had fallen? A. Such a thing might he—we have cases of pains of the head daily—I do not remember a case where I could not trace the cause of inflammation—intemperance would cause inflammation of the brain—I should not naturally expect to find some external mark from the descrip
tion given by the witnesses—inflammation might arise without external marks—if she fell on the curb-stone I should certainly expect to find a mark, or if she had been struck against any hard substance—I knew no
thing of the woman's habits.

JURY. Q. When she first came to you did not she draw your attention to marks on her head? A. None whatever—she merely said she had received a violent blow on the left side of her head on the previous evening—if a scar had been made so as to draw blood I should have seen it, or if there was a scar where she fell—I examined her very minutely indeed.
JOHN THOMAS TAYLOR . I am a parish constable. I apprehended the prisoner at the Jury-room.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe when you spoke to him, he said he hid struck his wife, and was very sorry for it? A. Yes, and seemed very penitent.

ESTHER FRANCIS . I am the wife of a Greenwich pensioner. I know the prisoner, and knew his wife—we lived in the same house—I think if the man had had a wife accordingly, he would have been as good a husband it ever was—she kept very bad hours—I never saw him hit her—she used to come in at all times in the night—she used to come up to our room, and greatly to annoy us—at times she was perfectly sober, and I have seen her quite tipsy, not often—I saw her once up at the turnpike after twelve o'clock, quite tipsy—her late hours were frequent—I they did not live in our house at the time this happened, and I know nothing of it.

COURT. Q. How long before the 25th of June bad you seen her? A. She came over to my house, and said her head was very bad—she was sub
ject to a very bad head—she always complained of her head ever since I knew her, which was ten months.

2283.
ACRE GRANT was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of August 1 shirt, value 1s., the goods of
William Dunn.

EMMA DUNN . I am the wife of William Dunn—we live at Woolwich—the prisoner came to lodge in the same room with me and my husband—on the 8th of August, I went down stairs, and in about two hours after I missed my husband's shirt—this is it.

JOHN LYNN (police-constable R 204.) I received information—I pur
sued the prisoner, and found him with this shirt on him.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined Three Months.

2284.
MARY CONNOR was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of July, 9 yards of silk, value 1l. 16s., the goods of
Richard Shillingford:
also on the 24th July, 11 yards of silk, value 1l. 15s., the goods of
Wil
liam Cooper; to both of which she pleaded.

GUILTY .* Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2285.
GEORGE RANGER was indicted
for bigamy; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 48.—
Confined Six Months.

2286.
MARTHA REILLY was indicted
for stealing on the 6th of July, 1 purse, value 1d., and 4 shillings, the property of
William Buckthorpe.

ELIZA BUCKTHORPE . I am the wife of William Buckthorpe, a batcher. On the 6th of July, I was at a house in Woolwich—the prisoner was there—I pat my purse on the table—it had four shillings in it—Ihe prisoner went away, and I directly missed my purse—I he one now produced is the one I lost—it has only 1s. 1 1/2 d. in it now.
MARIA HILL . I am searcher at the station—I searched the prisoner, and found on her this purse, and 1s. 1 1/2 d. in it.

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Three Months.

2287.
CHARLES BELL was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of August, 1 ring, value 12s.; 1 breast-pin, value 5s.; 1 ink-stand, value 1s.; and 1 printed book, value 2s.; the goods of
Jemima Daniels.

JEMIMA DANIELS . I am single, and reside in Prospect-cottages, Shooter's-hill. On the morning of the 8th of August, I found my bureau had been broken open—it stood in my wash-house, and these ar
ticles were missing—I he ink-stand and book produced are mine.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. What day did you miss them? A. On Sunday, the 8th of August, they were taken—I did not dis
cover it till Monday morning.
MARIAN ESTHER DANIELS . I am single, and live with my sister—the bureau was secure on the Sunday.

SUSANNAH MARTHA PICKETT . I am servant to Miss Daniels—I he pri
soner used to work in the house—on this Sunday, I saw him putting the ink-stand into his pocket—he was then at the bureau—he had the lid of the bureau in his hand, and a chisel was on the top of the bureau—I said, "Charley, what are you doing?"—he held up his finger, and said, "Hush "—I said, "What are you doing?"—he said, "I shall have this," and put the ink-stand into his pocket.

Cross-examined. Q. What age are you? A. Twelve—I he prisoner is servant to Mrs. Phillips, who lives in the next house—she was repairing the lower part of her house, and the prisoner came into our wash-house to clean his shoes—I did not say any thing about this, as I was afraid the prisoner would beat me—he used very often to beat me—he once hit me on the arm with a hammer—he did not threaten to beat me for this—I told my mistress on Monday.
WILLLIAM GEORGE OSBORN (police-sergeant R 13.) I found a chisel on
the top of the bureau, and the marks on the bureau appeared to have been made by it.

JOHN WALKER (police-constable R 182.) When the prisoner had been taken, I heard him crying at the window of the station—I asked him what it was about—he said two old ladies who lived at Prospect-cottages, Shooter's-hill, had lost a ring and a pin—he said he knew nothing about them, but the ink-stand was by the manger—I went there, and found it.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined Four Days, and
Whipped.

2288.
JOHN STRACHAN FLEWEL was indicted
for stealing, on the 15th July, 1 box, value 2s. 6d.; 1 ear-ring, value 2s. 6d., and 1 pair of spectacles, value 5s.; the goods of
William Nordish; and that he had been before convicted of felony.

TERRY NORDISH . I am the wife of William Nordish—we live at Greenwich—in the beginning of July I left home, leaving my cash-box in charge of Mrs. Cotton—Ihere was a pair of spectacles and an earring in it—I have not found them.

MARY ANN COTTON . I received the cash-box to take care of on the 15th of July—I he prisoner's mother lodged in the house where I was—the prisoner slept in the room where the box was that night, and in the morn
ing he was gone, and the box also—I saw it safe at half-past nine o'clock the night before, and no one had been in the room but him from the time I saw it safe till he went out—he came back in three or four days—his mother accused him of it, and be said he took the box, and it was not of much value.

WILLIAM WILTON (police-constable R 216.) When the prisoner was remanded I asked him what it was for—he said for stealing a cash-box, but they would not find it out, as he had put it in Davy Jones's locker—he said he would not have taken it if he had known how little there was in it, that the woman had told a great story, instead of being 10s. in it, there was only 5s.
CHARLES GRINHAM (police-sergeant S 21.) I produce a copy of the prisoner's former conviction, which I got at Mr. Clark's office—(read)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2289.
JOSEPH KEATS was indicted
for stealing, on the 21st of Au
gust, 1 peck of a certain mixture of oats and beans, value 1s., and 2 bushels of chaff, value 1s., the goods of
William Pershouse.

JOHN WALKER . I am a policeman. On the 21st of August, at half-past eleven o'clock at night, I was in the Trafalgar-road, at Greenwich—I saw the prisoner go into a stable. belonging to Mr. Pershouse—he had nothing with him then—he was in about a quarter of an hour—he then came out with a sack on his back—he shut the door, and was going away—he got two or three yards off with the sack, when I took him by the shoulder and said I should take him to Mr. Pershouse—he said, "For God's sake don't take me, for the sake of my character; I will give you all the money I have got, which is 5l."—when I seized him, he dropped the sack.
Prisoner. I never said such a thing—I took the sack out of my cart, which I had there.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Was there a cart? A. I did not see it—I was within three yards of the stable door, standing behind some pales, which concealed me, so that I could see the prisoner, and he could not see me—I had been there three quarters of an hour.
COURT. Q. What did the sack contain? A. Beans, oats, and chaff, and some bits of brown paper were amongst it, that the prosecutor might identify it.
ROBERT TAYLOR (police-sergeant R 18.) I was with the other officer—what he has stated is correct.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you see any cart? A. No, I was standing behind a gate, which has some open palings—I was on one side of the gate, and Taylor on the other.

WILLIAM PERSHOUSE . This was my stable. I had been robbed, and told the officer to watch—I mixed this oats, beans, and chaff, so as to know it, about an hour and a half before it was taken—I had cut some brown paper and put among it—I know it to be the same—the prisoner was brought to me by the two officers—he said he brought the corn from the dealers—I said, "It is not worth while to tell stories, you will see when you get to the station that there is a mark in it"—he then said, "It was pot handy for me."
(James Kite, a haberdasher, of Greenwich, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 28.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2290.
ELIZABETH NEWNHAM was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of August, 3 rings, value 30s., the goods of
Samuel M'Clellan, her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

2291.
ANN KITCHEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 10th of Au
gust, 1 sovereign, 1 half-crown, 1 shilling, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Henry Leman.
The prosecutor did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

2292.
GEORGE WATTS and
WILLIAM JONES were indicted for
a misdemeanour.
NOT GUILTY .

2293.
ROSA GRADY was indicted
for a conspiracy; upon which no evidence was offered.
NOT GUILTY .

2294.
JOHN FERNAN was indicted
for embezzlement.
GEORGE AUGUSTUS BEAURAIN . I am clerk to Mr. George Franks, a

surgeon, in Blackfriars-road—The prisoner was in his service, On the 7th of August, I gave him a sovereign to fetch'oil—I am in the habit of pay
ing for the oil used in the bouse—we always have two gallons at a time—the prisoner returned and gave me a shilling—The price we usually pay is 9s. 6d. a gallon—he was to go to Zetterquist's, in Blackfriars-road, first—he was not told to go there then, but I have told him before, and it is where we dealt.

Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPHUS. Q. Do you mean there is any particular connexion between Mr. Zetterquist and the prosecutor, which made it necessary to get the oil there? A. No, but at the beginning of winter we could not get good oil, and on that occasion I told him to go to Zetterquist's—I do not mean to say he was obliged to go there always—he was master's groom and porter—he was not told to buy two gallons—I did not examine how much oil there was in the house when he went—whether there might be another gallon in the house which he bought elsewhere, I cannot tell—it was Mr. Franks's sovereign I gave him—I took it out of the cash-box.

MR. ESPINASSE. Q. Did you know whether your master was in the habit of dealing with Zetterquist? A. Yes, for various things—The pri
soner was told to go there, and we thought he was in the habit of going there.

ELISHA KNIGHT . I am an oilman, and live in Charlotte-terrace, New Cut. On the morning of the 7th of August, the prisoner came to my shop, and bought one gallon of oil—he gave me a sovereign—I gave him 11s. change—I think it was a five-shilling piece, two half-crowns, and a shilling—he returned to the shop a little after one o'clock, and said his master and a friend had been inquiring about the oil, and if they came he hoped I should say it was two gallons he bad—he said he had purchased one gallon a short time before, which he paid for out of his own pocket—he said if I did not say so, he should get the cook and housemaid, and all of them into a scrape, that they would get the sack—he staid some time beg
ging hard of me to say it was two gallons—I told him it was a system I did not approve of, and if he had purchased a gallon before, it would be quite satisfactory to Mr. Franks to say so—I urged him to tell the truth, saying it would be a gross falsehood on my part to say it was two when it I was only one—Mr. Franks and Mr. Harvey then came in.

Cross-examined. Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A. About a month—he had not purchased another gallon of oil at my shop, that I am aware of—I have only served him once—he was ten minutes with me desiring me to say he had had two gallons—his master then came in—he spoke to him, and then went away—I live very nearly the same dis
tance from the prosecutor's as Mr. Zetterquist does—it is not two minutes difference—when the prisoner came the second time, he bought 1d. worth of rotten-stone to polish harness.

GEORGE FRANKS . I am a surgeon. I was at home on the 7th of Au
gust, when the prisoner came in and put 1s. down—he said, "That is the change from the oil"—he did not say what quantity—I asked him where he got the oil—he said from Mr. Knight, in the Cut (I had been to Irongalf Wharf, and meant to go again) I told him to go below and forward his work and to get his dinner, and at three o'clock to put the horse to, and I would go with him to Irongate Wharf—shortly after I went with Mr. Harvey, a friend of mine, and an acquaintance of Mr. Knight's, to Knight's shop—Mr. Harvey

went through the shop into the parlour, and I saw the prisoner come out from the parlour in about five minutes—I said, "What do you do here?"—he said he came to speak to Mr. Knight about the oil, as he thought I seemed to suspect all was not right—I said he had no business to do that, I did not complain about the oil—I had not expressed any suspicion up to that time—I told him to go home—he then said he came to boy some harness polish, which he had in his hand—after saying a few words to Mr. Knight, I got a policeman and gave him into custody—The prisoner asked why I did so—I said it was on a charge of felony—he said, "I know, sir, that I have done wrong respecting the oil, I assure yon that I bought a gallon about ten days back, that I ought then to have men
tioned it to Mr. George; I know that it is very wrong that I did not"—I said, "Well, John, but you have charged 9s. 6d. a gallon, and only paid Mr. Knight 9s."—he replied he certainly did pay Mr. Knight 9s. 6d.—he then alluded to the box at the Irongate Wharf—I said, "Well, you will put on your coat and go with the police," and I gave him in charge.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had he been in your service? A. Six or seven months—in that time I pose he bought six or eight gallons of oil for me—I did not see how much oil I had in my possession at this time—I cannot tell whether he had bought any within ten days or not—he gave me that account immediately on my speaking to him—according to the con
sumption of oil in my house, it is not likely it should have been bought and used—I should say there ought not to have been any wanted—The prisoner said, "If you measure the oil in the house, yon will find there was the gallon I have just now bought, and about half a gallon, which was in the can before I went for it"—I did not measure—I had no particular reason for not doing so.

Q. Supposing you had measured, and found the gallon newly brought, and the half-gallon also remaining, would that have satisfied you that what he said was correct? A. It would not certainly, because there would have been no reason for his getting the oil if there was some in the house—half a gallon will last us for some time—he never paid for oil out of his own pocket—I should say the two gallons we had before ought to have lasted—I do not, of my own knowledge, know when those two gallons were purchased, only from the books.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Three Months.

2295.
JOHN FERNAN was again indicted
for feloniously and know
ingly uttering a forged and altered receipt for the sum of 1s. 6d., with intent to defraud
George Franks.

GEORGE AUGUSTUS BEAURAIN . I am clerk to Mr. Franks, the pri
soner was in his service. On Friday, the 6th of August, I gave him a parcel to take to the Irongate-wharf, and book it for Dublin—here is the book he took with him—I did not give him any money at the time I gave him the parcel—he afterwards produced this receipt to me—I told him it had been altered, that the 6d. appeared to be added—he said it was just as he received it, that they took it back again from him, and he did not know whether they had altered it then—I paid him 18d., the sum men
tioned in the receipt—I afterwards made a communication to Mr. Franks—it was Mr. Franks's money I paid him.
Cross-examined by MR. ADOLPIIUS. Q. Whose writing is that book? A. This direction of the parcel was written by me before he went.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was all that is written in the last line written except the sum received and the initials of the person receiving it? A. All of it.

CHARLES RANFORD . I am clerk at the Irongate-wharf. I remember a person bringing a parcel to go by the Dublin steam-packet on Friday, the 6th of August—I received 1s. for it—this is the book the person I bringing the parcel presented to me—the 1s. written in this book is King
ston's, our foreman's, writing—it has his initial at the end—I received the money, and gave him the receipt now produced—I he "6d." has been added to it since—it was a receipt for 1s.—no other charge was made at the wharf.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he take the book away with him after your foreman wrote in it? A. Yes—I cannot swear to the prisoner, but it was this book which the person brought.
COURT. Q. Did you see the book yourself? A. Yes, I made the charge from the book.
JOSEPH KENT . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner in charge on Saturday, the 7th of August.
Cross-examined. Q. Did not he say 18d. had been paid when you took him? A. He did say so.

GUILTY .—
Confined Two Years, to commence from the expiration of the former Sentence.

2296.
MARY ANN RYAN was indicted
for feloniously receiving, of a certain evil-disposed person, on the 30th of June, 4 bonnets, value 1l. 10s., the goods of
George Hunt, well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

MARY HUNT . I am the wife of George Hunt, of Well-street, Southamp
ton-street, Camberwell; I keep a straw-bonnet shop. On the 30th of June, between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, three young women came into my shop and looked at some Tuscan bonnets, but bought no
thing—they were about to leave, when a customer came in—one of them then selected a bonnet at 10s. 6d., and placed it on the counter for me to wrap up; and in returning to place the other bonnets this was among into a box which was on the ground, she stooped down, as if she was putting them into the box, and hastily quitted the shop—I directly went to the box and missed four bonnets—I he young women were convicted at Hone
monger-lane on my charge—I here was another charge against them also—I have the four bonnets here—I they are all mine, and what I lost on that occasion, three Tuscan and one Rutland.

JAMES TIDMARSH . I am apoliceman. On the 30th of June I saw the pri
soner, in the Walworth-road, about six o'clock in the evening—I follwed her a considerable distance, nearly three-quarters of a mile, towards the Borough, when I saw another constable—I stopped her, and asked what she had got in her basket—she said she had her own property—I open it, and found seven bonnets there—I hese are four of them—she said she bought them in the lane, meaning Rosemary-lane—I stopped her about a mile from the prosccutrix's shop, within an hour of the robbery.

MARY M'CARTHY . I live in Peter-street, Soho. I have known the prisoner for the last ten years—she is a dealer in clothes—she has borne a very honest character—I have dealt in the fair for the last ten years—it is in Cutler-street, Petticoat-lane—it goes by the name of the Lane—all sorts of men and women's apparel is sold there, old bonnets, old hats, and every thing—it is very much frequented by Jews.

WILLIAM HENNESSEY . I am an engineer and smith. I have known the prisoner twenty years—I know she frequents the fair in Petticoat-lane and Cutler-street—sometimes there are so many people there you cannot get your foot through it; sometimes the policemen cannot get a passage through—she has borne a most undeniable character.

COURT. Q. Do you deal at the fair? A. No—I cannot say whether things are cheap there—they sell all kinds of apparel—I have seen Mrs. Kilday, the prisoner, there—I mean Ryan, Kilday is her former husband's name.

ELLEN MYERS . I am a widow, and live in Paradise-row. I have known the prisoner fifteen years to be a general-dealer in Petticoat-lane—I never heard of any charge against her—she has borne quite an honest character—I have got my living there all that time, with the exception of the Jews' holidays.

COURT. Q. What are the sort of dealings there? are goods sold at any price? A. There is everything, from 1d. to 10s. or 5s.—we do not inquire where they come from, we have no business to do so; it is an open fair—what we buy in the fair we sell again before we leave—I put it on my arm, and sell it back again if I can get 1s. or 6d.—I do not suppose any body would bring things dishonestly come by to an open place like that.

MARY HUNT
re-examined. The prisoner is not one of the three who took the bonnets—I he four bonnets together are worth about 2l.—the three women left my shop as near five o'clock as possible.

JAMES TIDMARSH , re-examined. I first saw the prisoner about six o'clock, about half or three-quarters of a mile from the prosecutrix's house, and about four miles and a half from Petticoat-lane—I stopped her in Newington-causeway.

GUILTY . † Aged 59.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

2297.
MARY PHILLIPS was indicted
for stealing, on the 24th of August, at Bermondsey, 7 sovereigns, the monies of
Peter Barralls, in his dwelling-house.

MARY BARRALLS . I am the wife of Peter Barralls, and live in Medley's place, in the parish of Bermondsey—it is his dwelling-house. On the 24th of August the prisoner came to assist me in washing—I had some sove
reigns wrapped up in a sock which I kept in a little press-bedstead—I saw them safe in the morning—she was gone, and I missed the sovereigns and the sock—I went and spoke to her about it in the morning—she told me she had taken them for safety—she said, "Yes, my dear, I have got them, and will return them to you again"—she put her hand into her pocket, took out a paper bag, and took out six sovereigns—I asked her what had become of the seventh—she told me she had changed it, and bought these things with it.
Prisoner's Defence." She asked me if I would go up stairs and make

the press-bed for a woman who was going to sleep in the house, as she was going to make away with herself; I said, "How can you think of doing so?" I made the bed, and this bag and money dropped out; I said to the little girl, "Take this purse down to your mother," and she took it down to her mother; I picked the sock up on the landing, and was going to throw it in the dust-hole.

MARY BARRALLS
re-examined. I had hid it in the press-bedstead for some time before that—there is no pretence for saying she came to take care of me.

GUILTY .—
Confined Six Months.

2298.
JOSEPH THOMPSON was indicted
for breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Daniel Birth, on the 14th of August, at Streatham, and stealing therein, 11 spoons, value 6l.; 1 ladle, value 10s.; and 9 forks, value 1l. 10s.; his goods.

ELIZABETH MERRITT . On the 14th of August I was in the service of Mr. Daniel Birth, of Upper Tooting—in the course of Saturday afternoon, the 14th of August, I was in the hall—there is a coach-house adjoining the house, under the same roof, and a communication from the coach-house into the house by a side door—I observed that the side door was shut half an hour before, but the coach-house door was open—I beard a noise of the gingling of plate—the plate was kept in a pantry—my master does not keep a footman—the housemaid takes care of the plate—I had seen it in the pantry ten minutes before I heard the tinkling—on hear
ing it I ran down stairs, and saw two men running out at the coach-house door—I ran down stairs, and was close on them—I saw them through the side door—I hey had plate in their hands—the prisoner was one of them—had never seen him before, but I am quite certain he is the person—I ran after them, and called out "Thief"—they ran up a lane opposite the dwell
ing-house., and I after them, but lost sight of them—about four or five minutes after, I saw the prisoner brought back by Francis—he had nothing on him then—I went into the pantry, and missed the plate stated in the indictment—these four table-spoons, three dessert forks, and three German silver forks now produced are Mr. Bin's property.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Did you speak to Francis about it before the prisoner was brought back by him? A. I told him the house had been robbed—I was not more than two yards from the persons I saw running away from the coach-house door at first, but when they jumped over the fence I lost sight of them—I saw the prisoner's face as he was opening the latch-gate to leave the premises—I saw his face quite plain—I am not swearing to him by his dress at all—he was dressed the same as be is now—I am positive of that, and am quite sure he is the same person—I have always been so—I saw him searched, but nothing was found on him.

THOMAS FRANCIS . I am a jobbing gardener, and work for Mr. Birth sometimes. On the 14th of August I heard Merritt shout out "Thief—she came up the lane, and gave an alarm that the house had been robbed of some plate—I and Benfield followed the prisoner into the garden of a woman named Cockett—Benfield said he thought he saw something un
derneath the beans—I went into the beans, and there found the prisoner secreted—I do not know whether he was lying or crouching down—the beans were seven or eight feet high—Benfield searched the place, and found

the plate—I caught hold of the prisoner, and Benfield assisted me, and went for the police—the prisoner said, "What do you want of me?"—I said, "I want that plate you have brought from over the way from Mr. Birt's house"—he said, "What plate? I have no plate"—and when the policeman searched him he had nothing on him—it was about 130 or 140 yards from Mr. Birt's house that I found him, and about five minutes after Merritt spoke to me.

Cross-examined. Q. You did not see any other person? A. No, only one—I saw Benfield find the plate, and he gave it into my hands imme
diately—he found it on the ground, exactly on the spot where the prisoner was, close to him—the prisoner's clothes were not unbuttoned, that I could perceive—I did not ask him what he was doing there, and do not recollect that Benfield did—I heard nothing pass about his being there to ease himself.
